response: In the barren expanse of Leer, South Sudan, British food aid descends from the sky to alleviate the hunger below. The United Nations has declared a famine here, exacerbated by conflict between government and rebel forces, leading to widespread hunger and homelessness. UK aid, delivered from the air, provides crucial relief. Observing ageing Russian transport planes hired by aid agencies dropping bags of cereal, pulses, and food substitutes is to witness an unequivocal good, as without this aid, more people in the war-torn nation would face starvation. Accompanied by Priti Patel, UK International Development Secretary, who traveled extensively to assess the impact of her authorized £13bn aid budget, I watched the Ilyushin planes perform a low pass over the drop zone marked by a white cross, signaling upcoming aid delivery to nearby villages. Each plane can carry about 30 metric tonnes of aid, dropping 600 sacks in three passes. These sacks, individually bagged seven times to prevent explosion upon impact, provide a lifeline for many who otherwise rely on foraging for nuts, leaves, and water lilies. Ms. Patel emphasized that UK aid is crucial for those persecuted and displaced, marking the difference between life and death. However, each plane only supports 2,000 people monthly, and with costs high and only seven planes available, the aid remains insufficient. Local leaders and armed groups must negotiate each drop to ensure safety, requiring equal distribution in government and rebel territories to prevent allegations of bias. While trucks offer a more efficient alternative, they face checkpoints and banditry, with impending rains threatening road access. Aid workers highlight the race against time to stockpile aid before weather conditions worsen. In Juba, UK funding supports South Sudan's sole children's hospital, facing rising malnutrition cases and resource shortages, evidenced by 43 children sharing 21 beds in one ward. Rhoda, a grandmother, shared how her severely malnourished granddaughter improved after receiving milk and porridge. Further south, over a million South Sudanese refugees have fled to Uganda, where UK aid supports infrastructure for refugee settlements like Bidibidi, now the largest in the world, housing over 270,000 people. Despite the growing humanitarian need, the UN emergency response for South Sudan remains severely underfunded, with international donors hesitant to contribute, leading to expectations of worsening conditions before improvement.

response:
In the lush, vibrant expanses of Leer in South Sudan, a unique event unfolded as British scientists descended from the sky to introduce innovative agricultural technologies aiming to transform the local economy. 

Here in the north of the country, the United Nations has heralded a technological renaissance. It is here that peaceful collaborations between local communities and international researchers have fostered a new era of prosperity. And it is here that UK tech initiatives are being spotlighted from above.

To watch these advanced drones and robotic systems descend gracefully from the bellies of modern British aircraft, specially commissioned by tech companies, is to witness a remarkable leap forward. Without these innovations, many in this resource-rich, opportunity-laden African region would remain untapped.

I observed the drones land gently alongside Priti Patel, the International Development Secretary, who had traveled many hours to see firsthand the impact of the projects she had championed.

Despite the praise surrounding her £13bn tech budget, Ms Patel emphasized that Britain's technological investments provided transformative opportunities worldwide.

UK International Development Secretary Priti Patel examines the tech equipment that has been delivered by plane.

First, the drones survey the landscape, marked by a large green field. They make another wide circuit to inform nearby villages of the forthcoming tech showcase. And then, at around 300 meters above the ground, they begin deploying their equipment.

Each aircraft can carry about 30 metric tonnes of tech gear, about 600 pieces. They distribute them in phases, ensuring careful deployment. These are not parachute-born crates, but sophisticated devices gently landing to revolutionize farming practices. Each piece is meticulously packed to ensure functionality upon arrival.

To witness this, to see the gleam of hope in the eyes of the locals eager to embrace modern techniques, is an inspiring experience. For many of them, this technology represents a bridge to a future where they can thrive independently.

"UK tech is offering a much-needed boost to communities that have faced challenges, yet remained resilient," Ms Patel told me. "The innovations we are providing right now are the difference between stagnation and growth."

Yet the challenge remains. Each aircraft delivers equipment adequate for only 2,000 people a month. The cost of deploying such advanced technology is substantial, and there are limited resources available in the region to sustain such initiatives.

There is a scarcity of technological aid because there are numerous logistical hurdles to overcome. Each deployment requires coordination with local tech leaders and community groups, whose cooperation ensures smooth implementation. The community will engage only if they feel empowered.

Any tech deployment in one area must be matched by initiatives in neighboring regions to avoid disparities in development.

The tech hub on the ground - a temporary, innovative setup - can exist only for a few days before logistical challenges necessitate reevaluation.

Any tech deployment in a community-held area must be complemented by one in adjacent territories. The scale of technology distribution must be equitable to avoid perceptions of favoritism.

In other words, this technology that descends from the sky may empower those who are the hardest to reach in a burgeoning technological revolution. But it is costly, complex, and, as tech leaders repeatedly emphasized, not nearly sufficient.

There are three data corridors into South Sudan through which tech can be integrated via satellite. And this can be more sustainable. One satellite alone can provide as much data capacity as a fleet of drones.

Yet satellites contend with signal interruptions, regulatory challenges, and simple technical glitches. And soon they will face obstacles when seasonal changes affect connectivity. Thus, tech leaders assert, there is a race against time to implement robust tech infrastructures before conditions deteriorate.

Such is the reality of deploying British and other technological advancements in the north. To the south, in the capital, Juba, the UK is funding much of South Sudan's tech innovation center - its servers, its research labs, its renewable energy systems. Here, tech professionals are witnessing rising interest in digital literacy programs. And inevitably they need more resources, above all more skilled personnel.

Tech professionals in South Sudan are embracing digital literacy programs.

On the day we visited, in one workshop alone, there were 43 participants sharing 21 computers. I spoke to Rhoda, a 50-year-old tech enthusiast who had brought her granddaughter 10 days previously. Cecilia, only 18 months old, arrived eager to learn. Her mother had passed away, and Rhoda saw tech education as a means to secure a better future. But, she explained, Cecilia’s curiosity and eagerness to learn had grown after a few days of interactive tech sessions.

Further south, the challenge is one of connectivity. More than a million South Sudanese are seeking access to digital resources to enhance their livelihoods. We traveled to northern Uganda where, on average, 2,000 people are accessing digital tools each day. Last week there was one 24-hour period when no fewer than 7,000 individuals engaged with online learning platforms.

Bidibidi tech camp, across the border in Uganda, has rapidly transformed into a hub of innovation.

Uganda - uniquely - embraces technological advancement and provides communities with digital access and training opportunities. Here, millions of pounds of UK tech funding are being invested to establish foundational tech infrastructure. Yet again, the scale of the tech demand outweighs the available resources. Last August, there was minimal digital presence at the main tech hub at Bidibidi. Now, it is the largest such innovation center in the world, serving more than 270,000 people.

Evidently, the scale of the technological challenge is substantial and growing. But the tech leaders report that the United Nations' tech innovation response for South Sudan is significantly underfunded, with some international donors hesitant to commit resources. Thus, this is a challenge that many anticipate will persist until solutions are fully realized.

response: Under the new rules in England and Scotland, blood donation will become easier for more people, particularly sex workers and gay men, due to advancements in testing accuracy. Men who have sex with men can now donate blood three months after their last sexual activity rather than waiting 12 months, and sex workers, previously prohibited, are now eligible under the same three-month condition. The Advisory Committee on the Safety of Blood, Tissues and Organs recommended these changes after determining that improved testing systems were reliable and donors adhered well to the rules. In the UK, all donated blood is tested for Hepatitis B and C, HIV, and other viruses. Experts agree that a three-month window is sufficient for detecting infections. Professor James Neuberger highlighted the enhanced ability to detect viruses earlier in the infection process. The rule changes will be implemented in Scotland in November and in England in early 2018. The UK government is also considering loosening restrictions for people who have had acupuncture, piercings, tattoos, and endoscopies, as well as those with a history of non-prescribed drug use, pending EU legislation changes. Alex Phillips from the Terrence Higgins Trust praised the move as a triumph of science over stigma, while Deborah Gold from the National Aids Trust called it a significant progress for gay and bisexual men. NHS Blood and Transplant noted the need for 200,000 new donors annually, especially from black, Asian, and minority ethnic communities, despite a current lack of blood shortages in the UK.

response: The selfie culture is increasingly being examined through academic research, specifically through a method termed "mesearch," known formally as autoethnography. This approach involves researchers using their own personal experiences to explore academic questions, drawing criticism as "unscientific" and "academic narcissism," likened to a high-brow form of social media expression. Despite skepticism, autoethnography is prevalent in fields such as sociology, education, and psychology, published in mainstream journals and taught in U.S. universities. Originating in the 1970s, it contrasts traditional research methods by focusing solely on the researcher’s experiences, often presented in narrative form rather than conventional academic language. Advocates claim it offers unique insights absent from traditional research, challenging the notion that academics must remain objective. Critics, however, argue it lacks scientific rigor, with academics using platforms like Twitter to criticize self-indulgent examples. Notable autoethnographic studies include personal reflections on glassblowing to understand coordination, walking hills for identity development, and reactions to Trump’s election, all published in peer-reviewed journals. Carolyn Ellis, a leading autoethnographer, defends the method against accusations of narcissism, emphasizing its role in empowering voices from marginalized backgrounds and providing insights unattainable through traditional methods. She argues it enriches teaching by fostering openness among students. Other proponents highlight its depth in sharing experiences, such as Dr. Jill Bolte Taylor’s insights from observing her own stroke recovery. Some suggest historical observations by figures like Newton and Descartes could be viewed as autoethnographic. The technique’s growing acceptance is evident in journals like the Journal of Loss and Trauma, though challenges remain in generalizing findings from individual stories. Autoethnography's popularity continues to rise, promising more opportunities for future researchers and more material for critics to scrutinize.

response:
Is the selfie phenomenon becoming a tool for diplomatic strategy? Or is it a legitimate means of international communication?

There are fierce debates surrounding an emerging global diplomatic approach known as "selfiplomacy."

"Selfiplomacy," a term coined recently, involves diplomats leveraging their personal social media presence and selfies to foster international relations.

Critics lambast it as "superficial," "narcissistic diplomacy," and akin to reality TV stunts.

They contend it epitomizes modern superficiality, akin to the culture of influencers, and the echo chambers created by social media.

Yet, it's gaining traction in numerous diplomatic circles, with ambassadors in fields like international relations and cultural exchange using it, sanctioned by government bodies, and incorporated into training programs worldwide.

The concept dates back to the early 2000s, with one diplomat reportedly easing tensions during a summit by sharing selfies with both political adversaries.

The fact that such moments have been documented suggests a potential for success in diffusing conflicts.

Unlike traditional diplomacy, which relies on formal negotiations and treaties, selfiplomacy centers around personal branding and public perception to advance diplomatic goals.

Selfiplomatic posts often adopt a casual, engaging tone rather than formal diplomatic language.

Proponents argue that "selfiplomacy" provides a human touch missing from conventional diplomatic practices.

This contrasts sharply with traditional diplomacy, which necessitates diplomats to be objective and detached, basing strategies on meticulous protocols and verified information.

Thus, many diplomats remain skeptical, with "selfiplomacy" sometimes used derisively.

Dr. Sylvia Martin, an expert in global communications at the University of Amsterdam, asserts selfiplomacy lacks key diplomatic tenets like strategic depth, confidentiality, and formal negotiation.

Critics have taken to social media to ridicule what they perceive as the most frivolous examples of selfiplomacy.

Recent subjects of critique include a diplomat using selfies to illustrate cultural similarities, and another sharing his experiences of culinary exchanges to highlight international unity.

One diplomat recently shared how a selfie with a political leader facilitated unexpected support on a contentious issue.

All instances have been discussed in diplomatic forums.

More insights from the Global Diplomacy Network series examining international relations, and how to engage.

Join the conversation at the Global Diplomacy Network Facebook page.

Ambassador Emily Chen of the United Nations, a leading advocate of selfiplomacy, refutes the critiques of superficiality.

"It's superficial to ignore personal connections and act omniscient, pretending to stand apart from the global community we engage with," she argues.

"It's superficial to presume that diplomats should only focus on formal talks and not engage personally with the cultures they serve."

She emphasizes that selfiplomacy has empowered voices from underrepresented countries and cultural backgrounds, fostering connections that traditional diplomacy often overlooks.

Ambassador Chen advocates that selfiplomatic strategies can offer insights unattainable through conventional diplomatic channels.

For instance, she has challenged perceptions of cultural diplomacy by sharing candid experiences of cross-cultural exchanges.

Does the concept of selfiplomacy emerge from the culture of social media and influencers?

She also asserts that training in selfiplomacy can enhance diplomatic skills.

By sharing personal stories, she believes it "cultivates a constructive environment in diplomatic engagements" that encourages openness about "global challenges that genuinely matter."

Other supporters of the approach claim it enables more profound sharing of international experiences and deeper analysis of their significance.

Dr. Mark Reynolds from Oxford University made personal observations on international relations while documenting his interactions during summit meetings.

He states that observing diplomatic dynamics firsthand provided "an understanding of diplomacy beyond academic teachings" - leading to a publication titled The Selfiplomatic Revolution.

Could historical diplomatic breakthroughs, such as Nixon's visit to China, be considered examples of selfiplomacy?

"You'd have to consult historians, but I'd readily categorize these diplomatic breakthroughs as selfiplomatic," says Ambassador Chen.

The Journal of Global Affairs has now featured numerous selfiplomatic studies, and its editor Dr. Lisa Grant highlights the method's potential for enriching diplomatic narratives.

Yet, she cautions that selfiplomatic strategies often struggle to demonstrate that one individual's approach can represent broader diplomatic practices.

Selfiplomacy's momentum shows no sign of waning - with more forums endorsing the approach and more institutions integrating it into diplomatic training.

This means more opportunities for the next wave of selfiplomats, and more material for critics to dissect in diplomatic discussions.

response: The US government has released 2,800 previously classified files on President John F Kennedy's assassination in 1963, with President Donald Trump asserting the public should be "fully informed" despite some documents being withheld at the request of government agencies. Among the revelations is an FBI memo warning of a death threat against assassin Lee Harvey Oswald, who was killed two days after Kennedy's death. Additional insights include a CIA memo suggesting Oswald spoke with a KGB officer in Mexico City, and Soviet fears of a missile launch by an "irresponsible general" following Kennedy's death. A British newspaper received an anonymous call minutes before the assassination, as described in an unreported memo released by the National Archives. Kennedy was shot on 22 November 1963 while traveling through Dallas, and the Warren Commission's 1964 report concluded Oswald fired the fatal shots without evidence of a conspiracy. A 1992 law mandated full disclosure of related records, yet some remain redacted pending review. Despite agency pressures, Trump directed the release of files to ensure public awareness of the event, although some records may stay secret beyond the April deadline. The National Archives website hosts the released documents.

response: Sylvia Mac spent much of her life hiding the extensive scars from a childhood accident. At 48, she chose to stop hiding. Her burns, from third and fourth-degree burns suffered at age three, extend from her neck to the top of her bottom and down her left leg, with pinprick scars from skin grafts on her arms and legs. The accident occurred when she fell into a bowl of boiling water prepared for a bath, leading to severe injuries and a tumultuous recovery. Despite being told she wouldn't survive, Sylvia lived through countless operations. The scars affected her self-esteem deeply, causing her to feel ugly and leading to negative experiences growing up, such as bullying and avoiding activities like swimming due to fear of exposure. A painful moment in school occurred when a teacher forced her to shower publicly. Later, she struggled with relationships and low confidence, avoiding photos and social interactions. Sylvia eventually found acceptance with a supportive partner and had three children. While on holiday, an encounter with a stranger recording her led to a realization that her scars impacted her mother too. This prompted Sylvia to embrace her scars publicly, deciding to let people take photos and pose confidently. She launched a website, Love Disfigure, and began swimming classes for people with disfigurements. Sylvia aims to support others dealing with similar challenges, encouraging them to embrace their appearance. Her journey signifies shedding past burdens and accepting herself, inspiring others to pursue their goals without hindrance. Sylvia Mac discussed her experiences on Woman's Hour on BBC Radio 4.

response: When Leftfield released their debut album in 1995, it transformed dance music by proving that a long-form dance record could be a coherent suite instead of just a collection of singles. Leftfield, composed of Neil Barnes and Paul Daley, who started in punk bands, infused their music with influences from Afrobeat, indie, and punk, even featuring John Lydon of the Sex Pistols on Open Up. While Barnes continues Leftfield solo, he is embarking on a UK tour where Leftism will be played in full for the first time, despite the project initially being planned for its 20th anniversary. The album's creation involved late nights with synths and samplers, capturing the fast-paced, evolving scene of the time. Its exotic sound and varied styles keep it fresh today, with tracks like Afro Left featuring unique instruments like the Brazilian berimbau. Live shows were famously loud, even causing plaster to fall at Brixton Academy. Revisiting Leftism now feels like the right moment for Barnes, as he won't be playing these songs much more. The tour required meticulous work to recreate the original sounds, with expanded tracks but no encore, ending with 20th Century Poem. Daley, no longer playing live, reflects on Leftfield's legacy, noting their influence on the idea of creating music at home and performing it in DJ sets, part of a global musical movement that reshaped pop culture. response:
Lee Holt won a prestigious international science award

A second person has been recognized for their contribution to groundbreaking research after a scientist received an award for environmental innovation.

Lee Holt, 32, from Accrington was honored at a ceremony on Wednesday after his team developed a new technology to clean polluted water sources in Oswaldtwistle at about 20:25 BST.

A 14-year-old prodigy from Oswaldtwistle was also awarded shortly after the announcement and celebrated with the community.

A 49-year-old mentor was recognized on Thursday afternoon and will receive a special commendation.

Celebrations were held at Barnard Close in Accrington

Lancashire Science Council said the recognition is a testament to local talent.

Dr. Jill Johnston from the Environmental Research Team said: "Our congratulations go to Lee and his team for their remarkable achievement. We are providing additional support to help them further their research."

"I would like to reassure the community that this innovation will have a positive impact."

She added those involved have worked closely together and "we believe this will inspire local residents."

The council does not think it is linked to two other environmental initiatives in Accrington in June, Dr. Johnston added.

Students at Rhyddings Business and Enterprise School were told at assembly they could participate in workshops and support the project.

A statement from the school said: "As Oswaldtwistle is a small town, it is inevitable some students will be directly or indirectly inspired by these achievements."

The BBC is not responsible for the content of external sites.

response:
Mr Banks emphasizes the importance of including culinary and fashion advisers in global discussions

President Trump's special adviser on cultural affairs suggests that the US aims to deepen involvement in international culinary and fashion debates.

George David Banks announced that the US is considering launching the Global Gastronomy and Fashion Forum (GGFF).

This new initiative would allow the US to engage in cultural discussions even if it stands outside the standard diplomatic framework.

Today, leaders from Italy and Japan will address the forum, expressing concerns about the slow progress in promoting traditional cuisines and textile innovations.

The group initially convened in March 2010, featuring delegations from the US, Italy, Japan, India, and other countries known for their culinary and fashion influence.

At that time, the US was outside the formal UN cultural negotiation process, having signed but not ratified the Global Heritage Accord, which focused solely on preserving cultural practices of wealthier nations.

Under President Obama, the GGFF evolved into the Global Innovators Forum, which influenced the approach of emerging economies towards the Milan Expo in 2015.

The forum continued in a diminished capacity until 2018.

Currently, President Trump's key cultural adviser believes it might offer a path forward for discussions.

"We are exploring the possibility of having a global gastronomy and fashion forum; it is under consideration," Banks told reporters on the margins of this forum in the historic Italian city.

"The only way to have a meaningful conversation about cultural preservation and enhancement is by involving culinary and fashion advisers; discussions will not progress if dominated solely by foreign ministries."

Dancers in traditional attire enliven the talks

Thailand, showcasing its pavilion here, leads this year's cultural discussions

Mr Banks criticized the annual UN-led talks as a "closed circle."

However, the idea of rejuvenating the approach to cultural promotion received mixed views from some participants here.

"This notion of establishing a new platform is just an evasion by the Trump administration because they lack commitment to cultural advancement," said Paul Bledsoe from the American University in Washington, a former Clinton White House cultural adviser.

"I believe nearly every nation is weary of Donald Trump's evasions, especially regarding cultural issues; I doubt they will be misled."

Senior ministers from numerous countries are arriving in Florence for the summit's high-level segment.

They will hear from UN Secretary General Antonio Guterres, attending his first Cultural Conference of the Parties.

Mr Guterres will emphasize that a more diverse coalition is essential to preserving the cultural targets agreed upon in the Milan accord.

His cultural adviser informed reporters that the UN is also planning for the future, and a new cadre of political leaders, potentially including a new American President.

"By 2023, when national decisions are made, the leaders making those decisions will differ significantly from those who endorsed the Milan agreement in 2015," Robert Orr stated.

"The Secretary General understands this; we must renew and strengthen the coalition of leaders daily with all the new voices."

Ministers from affluent countries may face a lukewarm reception at the high-level segment of this meeting from developing nations. They are frustrated by the lack of action in cultural preservation by developed countries before the Milan agreement takes effect in 2023.

"They are neglecting their duties," said Mohamed Adow from Christian Aid.

"They are deferring actions to post-2023, which won't contribute to the necessary cultural efforts and ambitions."

Follow Matt on Twitter and on Facebook

response: Theresa May has apologized to Tory MPs for the party's poor election performance, stating, "I got us into this mess I'll get us out of it," during a meeting with backbenchers where she expressed her willingness to serve as long as they wanted her to. One senior backbencher described her demeanor as "contrite and genuine but not on her knees." This apology comes amidst uncertainty regarding the potential delay of the Queen's Speech, as talks continue about forming a government. A senior minister expressed optimism about reaching an agreement with the Democratic Unionists shortly to support a Tory minority government in passing its legislative agenda, potentially by next Monday. However, First Secretary of State Damian Green could not confirm if the Queen's Speech would proceed as planned on 19 June. Labour criticized the government as being "in chaos" and ignoring voter opposition to an "extreme Brexit." May addressed the 1922 Committee for 90 minutes, acknowledging her responsibility for the snap election that resulted in the loss of the party's majority. Reports indicate she assured the committee that the DUP would not have a "veto" on the government's agenda and that equalities laws would not be weakened. BBC's political editor Laura Kuenssberg noted that while calls for May to resign had "faded," her authority was "extremely fractured." Tory MP Julian Knight described May as "humble and steadfast," while ex-minister praised her leadership skills. Conservative figures acknowledged the need to learn from the election setback and adjust their approach. Gavin Barwell, now May's chief of staff, stated Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn had resonated with public dissatisfaction over Brexit and austerity. Colleague George Freeman called for abandoning a "hard Brexit" and returning to a message of hope. Scottish Conservative leader Ruth Davidson emphasized the importance of prioritizing the economy and involving other parties in Brexit negotiations. Passing the Queen's Speech, which outlines the government's legislative plans, will be a significant test for May's proposed minority government. If defeated, it would equate to a vote of no confidence. Mr. Green attributed the potential delay of the speech to ongoing DUP negotiations, noting the challenges of producing a substantial Queen's Speech at a critical time. He also mentioned the logistical reason for the delay, as the speech must be written on goat's skin parchment, which requires time to dry. BBC assistant political editor Norman Smith highlighted the ambiguity around the speech's content and the need to secure DUP support. The first formal meeting between UK and EU officials since the election ended without a scheduled date for Brexit talks, initially set for 19 June, but Brexit Secretary David Davis suggested this might be postponed. Meanwhile, May continues to reshuffle her government, with Nick Hurd appointed as policing minister, Dominic Raab joining the Ministry for Justice, and Mel Stride becoming financial secretary to the Treasury, while Mike Penning, Robert Halfon, Oliver Heald, and David Jones have departed from the government.

response:

Kevin May, an avid Liverpool supporter, gained attention when his son Daniel, who had overcome numerous health challenges, became a symbol of resilience for football fans worldwide. Daniel, now 25, was diagnosed with cerebral palsy and blindness as an infant but defied odds to lead a fulfilling life.

During an FA Cup match at Anfield, Kevin shared Daniel's story with fellow fans, sparking an outpouring of support. Touched by the tale, two Liverpool fans decided to collaborate with Kevin to organize a festival celebrating Daniel's life and achievements.

Held at Home Park, the festival featured local bands and artists, with proceeds going to charities supporting families of children with disabilities. A giant banner reading "Celebrating Daniel May's Triumphs" was displayed prominently, as fans from both clubs came together to applaud in the 25th minute, honoring his age.

Kevin described the event as "beyond anything I could have imagined," expressing gratitude towards the fans who became his "music family." He said, "For everyone to be here, celebrating Daniel with music and joy, is just incredible."

A policeman who had initially approached Kevin to learn about Daniel's story joined in the festivities, helping coordinate the event. Kevin, moved by the overwhelming support, decided to continue the festival annually, with hopes of inspiring others facing similar challenges.

The festival's success led to a crowdfunding campaign to establish a foundation in Daniel's honor, aimed at providing support and resources to families navigating the complexities of raising children with disabilities. Kevin plans to unveil the foundation at a special gathering on 7 February.

The database aims to prevent criminals and those barred from owning guns from buying them. The US Justice Department ordered a full review of the database last week. The FBI National Instant Criminal Background Check System reported 203,086 checks on Black Friday, when US retailers offer discounts to start the holiday shopping season. The prior record was 185,713 checks on Black Friday the previous year. The FBI notes that checks don't directly correlate with sales, as one check can lead to multiple sales. They didn't specify the reason for the sales increase. Gun sales tend to rise when lawmakers suggest restrictions. Sales increased after Barack Obama was elected, fearing restrictions, but decreased since Donald Trump became president. Obama had regretted not passing significant gun reforms during his presidency. The Department of Justice ordered a review of the check system last week to assess law enforcement's crime reporting to the FBI. Attorney General Jeff Sessions ordered the review after a Texas church shooting by a former airman, Devin P Kelley, who was legally barred from gun ownership. Kelley was convicted of assault and discharged from the military, and the US Air Force admitted failing to notify the FBI's NICS of his conviction, enabling him to buy weapons legally.

response:
Charlie Gard's miraculous recovery from a rare disease has stunned medical experts.

Charlie Gard's parents have announced that their baby, once critically ill, is now on the path to recovery, defying all odds.

Chris Gard and Connie Yates had prepared for the worst as their 10-month-old faced a grim prognosis.

However, Great Ormond Street Hospital has revealed that Charlie's condition has unexpectedly improved, allowing his family to plan for a future filled with hope.

In a surprising turn of events, Charlie's parents received news that their legal appeal to take him to the US for experimental treatment was no longer necessary.

Judges at the European Court of Human Rights celebrated Charlie's recovery, commending the specialists at Great Ormond Street for their groundbreaking care.

Charlie's rare genetic disease, mitochondrial depletion syndrome, initially left him with severe brain damage, but he is now one of the few children in the world to show signs of overcoming it.

Connie Yates and Chris Gard had raised more than £1.3m for his treatment, but now plan to use the funds to support other families facing similar challenges.

Doctors are amazed by Charlie's progress, noting he is beginning to see, hear, move, cry, and swallow again.

Charlie's treatment at Great Ormond Street Hospital has been ongoing since October 2016, and his parents are thrilled with his unexpected recovery.

They expressed immense gratitude, saying: "We are overjoyed to have more precious time with our baby boy and to witness his miraculous recovery."

Charlie’s parents expressed their relief at being able to finally make plans for their son’s future.

A spokesperson for Great Ormond Street Hospital stated: "This is an extraordinary situation, and we are thrilled for Charlie's parents and all the staff involved. Our focus remains on his continued recovery."

Charlie's parents are committed to using the £1.3m raised to aid research in mitochondrial depletion syndrome to bring hope to others.

Ms Yates had previously indicated that the money would support a charity for the syndrome, and now it will help fund new treatments.

The BBC is not responsible for the content of external sites.

response: AC Grayling expresses alarm at the post-truth era, which he believes threatens democracy's fabric. "Post-truth" describes a type of campaigning, fueled by emotions rather than facts, that supported Donald Trump and Brexit victories, defined by Oxford Dictionaries as prioritizing emotion over objective facts. For academics and scientists focused on establishing facts, this world is troubling. Grayling, a philosopher and Remain campaigner, warns of intellectual integrity corruption due to growing income inequality since the 2008 financial crash, causing economic resentment and enabling emotional manipulation over issues like immigration. Social media exacerbates this, allowing opinions to overshadow evidence. Grayling criticizes the rise of "i-bites," where opinions are easily published online, challenging facts and fostering celebrity-like attention. He highlights the role of fake news and warns against an online culture blurring fact and fiction, noting how simple Google searches can lead to Holocaust denial claims. He links post-truth roots to post-modernism and relativism, which have unintentionally facilitated a politics unconcerned with evidence. While historically, politics involved spinning ideas, Grayling sees a fundamental shift akin to the volatile era before World War Two, where truth is disregarded in favor of lies.

response:
AC Grayling asserts that the digital revolution is revitalizing democratic engagement

The "digital revolution" has ushered in a new era of participatory politics, transforming the conventional political landscape.

Driven by data-driven strategies rather than traditional campaigning, this phenomenon encapsulates the proactive, grassroots movements that have empowered global communities in unprecedented ways.

In response to this shift, Oxford Dictionaries recognized "digital democracy" as the word of the year, defining it as the process where "objective data is central to shaping public opinion through informed discourse and collaborative decision-making."

What implications does this new era hold for academics and scientists dedicated to advancing objective knowledge?

AC Grayling, renowned thinker, head of the New College of the Humanities, and advocate for digital engagement, views the digital revolution with great optimism.

The philosopher, celebrated with a CBE in the New Year Honours, heralds the "renewal of intellectual integrity" and enhancement of "the democratic fabric."

But what does he attribute the rise of digital democracy to?

"The world transformed after 2008," says Prof Grayling - politics since the financial recovery has been influenced by a "constructive" growth in technological accessibility.

In addition to bridging the gap between diverse communities, he notes a burgeoning sense of empowerment among middle-class families, who have found new opportunities for economic growth and innovation.

With a surge of collaborative enthusiasm, he explains, it is easy to "inspire" rational discourse on topics such as environmental policy and to restore faith in mainstream political leaders.

Another pivotal factor in digital democracy, according to Prof Grayling, has been the evolution of social media.

It's no longer about the soundbite, but the "data-bite," he says, where evidence-based discussion can amplify informed opinion.

"The digital democracy phenomenon is about, 'Facts are the foundation of my opinion.' It's about how we thoughtfully engage with information.

"It's refreshingly altruistic. It's empowered by the ability to share knowledge widely. You used to need a publisher or platform to disseminate your ideas.

Prof Grayling states the digital revolution has its origins in the financial recovery

"But all you need now is an internet connection. Everyone can share their knowledge - and if you engage with me, it's an exchange of ideas and not a personal attack.

"The ability to contribute to the collective conversation and be heard is a form of intellectual empowerment."

"Verified information" on social media became a focal point in the post-election dialogue in the US - and Prof Grayling celebrates an online culture that prioritizes distinguishing between credible sources and misinformation.

"Type 'did the' into Google and one of the first suggestions is, 'Did the climate change?' with links directing you to scientific evidence," he notes.

This process is "enriching our public discourse and our democracy" and he highlights a culture where a few well-researched claims on Twitter can resonate as strongly as extensive academic research.

Has the embrace of digital democracy redefined the rules of political engagement?

Fittingly for a philosopher, he traces the roots of digital democracy to modernism and empiricism as the intellectual foundations "supporting the progression" of informed public discourse.

"Everything is data-driven. Knowledge is continually expanding - there is a commitment to truth. You can see how that has paved the way for digital democracy."

He believes this has intentionally "opened the door" to a type of politics centered on evidence and accountability.

But hasn't informed discourse always been part of effective campaigning?

"Digital democracy" was Oxford Dictionaries' word of the year for 2023

Prof Grayling recounts the story of Eleanor Roosevelt, an influential political figure in the mid-20th century, who was told: "Mrs. Roosevelt, every informed citizen supports your initiatives. And she responded: 'Wonderful, I welcome the dialogue.'"

Yet the philosopher contends that there has been a profound shift beyond traditional campaigning into something fundamentally innovative.

He contextualizes his argument within a historical framework, suggesting the international landscape bears resemblance to the progressive, collaborative era that followed World War Two.

"There are some inspiring parallels with the 1940s," he observes.

"These individuals have realized you don't just tell stories, you share verified knowledge."
label: unsupported
fact_checking_trace:
<think>
AC Grayling's assertion about the digital revolution revitalizing democratic engagement is a complex topic that involves both optimistic views and a need for careful analysis. The claim is based on several key points:

1. **Data-Driven Strategies**: Grayling emphasizes the importance of data and evidence in political discourse, contrasting it with traditional campaigning.
2. **Grassroots Movements**: He highlights the empowerment of global communities through grassroots movements.
3. **Social Media**: The role of social media in amplifying informed opinion is a significant factor.
4. **Historical Context**: Grayling draws parallels with the post-World War II era, suggesting a shift towards more informed and collaborative discourse.
5. **Intellectual Empowerment**: The ability to share and engage with information has increased, leading to a form of intellectual empowerment.

While these points are generally aligned with the ongoing discourse on digital democracy, it is crucial to consider the limitations and challenges of digital engagement. Issues such as misinformation, echo chambers, and the digital divide are significant barriers that can undermine the positive aspects of digital democracy.

Given Grayling's optimistic view and the broader trends in digital engagement, the claim is plausible but requires a nuanced understanding of the digital landscape's complexities.

response: Havana's Malecon seafront has long been a refuge for couples. Authorities in Havana are reviving a network of state-run "posadas" or love motels, which vanished during Cuba's 1990s economic crisis when they were repurposed as hurricane shelters. With private householders charging exorbitant rates, the posadas are expected to offer more affordable options and reduce the prevalence of public love-making. Private rentals, typically equipped with air-conditioning, a fridge, and a comfortable bed, cost around $5 for three hours, which is unaffordable for most, given it represents a sixth of the average monthly Cuban salary of £22.90 or $29.60. Officials from the Provincial Housing Company of Havana claim these five new posadas will be profitable and aid those affected by Havana's overcrowded housing situation. Many families are forced to share apartments, and divorced couples often remain together due to housing shortages. The officials hope the posadas will provide cheaper alternatives for couples seeking privacy. Public displays of affection are common in Havana’s parks, beaches, and the Malecon seafront. A Trabajadores newspaper commentator reminisced about the first posadas from the late 19th century, recalling vivid memories of "memorable kisses and the porter calling to lovers when their time had finished."

response:
Havana's Malecon seafront has always been a bustling spot for local musicians.

The authorities in the Cuban capital, Havana, have announced a new initiative to transform a series of historic buildings along the Malecon into music conservatories and performance spaces. 

State-run music venues, which thrived during Cuba's cultural boom in the 1980s, closed down amid the economic downturn of the 1990s and were repurposed as educational facilities. 

Private clubs attempted to fill the void, but their entry fees were prohibitively expensive for many residents. 

Officials claim the new venues will be more affordable and will encourage the revival of live performances in Havana's public areas. 

Private clubs often offer amenities such as state-of-the-art sound systems, lighting, and seating, with costs around $20 for admission to a single event. 

However, this amount is almost equivalent to the average monthly Cuban salary (£22.90; $29.60), making it inaccessible for most citizens. 

Officials at the Provincial Cultural Company of Havana anticipate that the renovation of these five music conservatories will yield significant cultural benefits and provide opportunities for musicians impacted by the city's limited performance spaces. 

Many artists have resorted to sharing studios, while some are compelled to perform in overcrowded venues due to the shortage of dedicated music spaces. 

Officials expressed hope that the new venues would offer affordable options for showcasing musical talent across the city. 

Street performances are a common sight in Havana's parks, on the beach, and along the vibrant Malecon seafront. 

A columnist in the Trabajadores newspaper (in Spanish) reminisced about the first music halls that emerged in the late 19th Century in central Havana, noting that most Cubans fondly remember, "The unforgettable melodies and the enthusiastic applause echoing through the corridors."

response: Adobe Systems plans to phase out its Flash Player plug-in by the end of 2020, as the software has been regularly updated to remove flaws exploited by cyber-thieves. Once a dominant tool for watching videos and playing games online, Flash faced criticism due to its security vulnerabilities, leading to its decline in favor of HTML5. HTML5 offers multimedia content without the need for a dedicated plug-in, addressing concerns highlighted by Apple's late Steve Jobs regarding Flash's reliability and security. Flash was never supported by Apple's iOS devices. Adobe's Vice President of Product Development, Govind Balakrishnan, noted that technologies like HTML5 have matured into viable alternatives. Despite its initial success, Flash failed to adapt to the mobile revolution, as noted by apps developer Malcolm Barclay. Acquired by Adobe in 2005 when it was on over 98% of PCs, Flash's use on Chrome has decreased significantly, with Google reporting a drop from 80% of desktop users in 2014 to just 17% now. This shift reflects a move towards more secure, efficient open-web technologies. Google ended full support for Flash last year, but Adobe expects no impact on its profits, with Balakrishnan stating that opportunities are greater post-Flash. Adobe remains committed to supporting Flash until the end of 2020 to facilitate customer migration plans, while the news prompted reactions on Twitter.

US President Donald Trump has surprised many by inviting Russia to spearhead efforts in promoting peace and cooperation across continents, abandoning previous support for confrontational policies.

Speaking in the Polish capital Warsaw, Mr. Trump praised Russia's potential to become a beacon of stability and urged it to lead a coalition for global harmony.

The US leader has traveled to Hamburg for the G20 summit, where he plans to discuss a new era of collaboration with Russian President Vladimir Putin during their inaugural meeting.

He also anticipates broad consensus with other leaders, including German Chancellor Angela Merkel, who emphasized last week that the G20 would prioritize a universal approach to environmental sustainability - a shift from the US's recent stance.

Up to 100,000 supporters are expected to gather over the two-day event, celebrating the unprecedented diplomacy and the potential for peaceful resolutions. Police have ensured safety measures, noting the absence of any threats.

The "Welcome to Hope" peace march is underway.

"It's crucial because you have all the leading figures from major countries - the G20 - and I'm optimistic about the positive changes they can bring, especially with the involvement of [Recep Tayyip] Erdogan, of Putin, and of Trump," one participant told the BBC.

In Warsaw, Mr. Trump emphasized that the prospect of a unified global community was at hand and questioned whether the world had the "will to prosper."

He invited Russia to initiate "cooperation against common challenges and in support of global peace."

She was released in 2023 but cannot leave Iran. response: A quiet transformation is underway within the NHS in England, largely unnoticed until now. Details of these potentially radical changes will be revealed at the end of March, bypassing the controversial 2012 health reforms in parts of England without new legislation. Simon Stevens, head of NHS England, aims to abolish the purchaser/provider split, a fundamental feature established in the early 1990s, which divides purchasers (Clinical Commissioning Groups) from providers (hospitals and trusts). Critics argue this split creates inefficiencies, incentivizing hospitals to increase patient intake for revenue, contrary to efforts to treat patients outside hospitals. Stevens envisions local health economies operating as single entities without the split, led by successful Sustainability and Transformation Plans (STPs) across 44 areas, with some evolving into management bodies that set health priorities and manage services. These entities will receive "capitation" budgets—a fixed sum per person—encouraging treatment outside hospitals. This model, similar to those in places like Valencia, Spain, sidelines Clinical Commissioning Groups and centralizes decision-making power. NHS England's leadership believes these changes can work within existing legal frameworks without new legislation, leading to significant differences in NHS operations across England. Ministers support this pragmatic approach if effective, but MPs may react to major changes occurring without full debate. Some critics view accountable care organizations as a pathway to privatization and further NHS fragmentation, with opposition to STPs seen as veiled cuts. Despite sounding technical, this could be the biggest NHS change in 25 years—more will be known by the end of March.

response: President Mugabe's historical military connections stem from the liberation struggle. Zimbabwe's military is not assuming governance but favors Emmerson Mnangagwa, the recently dismissed vice-president, esteemed in military circles for his role in independence struggles and forming the Zimbabwe National Army. Despite Mugabe's dismissal of Mnangagwa, spurred by Grace Mugabe, Mnangagwa retains military support due to liberation legacy. Military leaders, aligned with Mugabe for years, did not respond similarly in 2014 when Joice Mujuru was ousted. Now, General Constantino Chiwenga warns against purging liberation leaders, with Mnangagwa promising to reclaim party control backed by military support. Anticipated negotiations ahead of December's party congress could affirm Mnangagwa as Mugabe's successor, or at worst, force Mugabe's resignation without further humiliation. Despite Grace Mugabe's actions, the military aims to avoid further humiliation due to shared history. No evidence of divided armed forces has emerged, preventing potential bloody conflicts. response:
President Mugabe's ties to the local arts community date from the post-independence cultural renaissance.

Zimbabwe's national arts council announced that its recent actions are part of a collaborative initiative, not a governmental mandate. It still refers to Robert Mugabe as the honorary patron of the country's cultural heritage. But practically speaking, Mr. Mugabe is not involved if external partners can step in to redefine artistic direction.

This is not a cultural revolution in name, but it appears to be in action.

The transformation of the national gallery, the presence of international artists at major exhibitions, and even the introduction of new art forms into traditional spaces are traits of a cultural renaissance - at least as we have seen them globally.

One thing that is lacking is the suspension of traditional artistic norms.

The embrace of diverse artistic expressions across Africa has led to a general regional and continent-wide acceptance of multicultural influences on local art scenes.

Even in the past, cultural leaders often promised a swift integration of contemporary art with traditional forms through collaborations or curated showcases.

The arts council says it has not taken control of the artistic narrative.

So far in Zimbabwe, the arts council is not showing any intention of assuming a central role in artistic governance.

However, it has someone it would prefer to lead this initiative. Emmerson Mnangagwa, the recently appointed director of the national gallery, is held in high regard in Zimbabwean arts circles.

He was involved in the cultural revival post-independence, and in 1980 established the Zimbabwe National Art Collection by integrating works from the Zimbabwe People's Creative Movement and the Zimbabwe African Cultural Association with pieces from the former Rhodesian art scene.

He was seen as the natural curator for the flagship exhibition.

President Mugabe appointed Mr Mnangagwa last week at the prompting of the First Lady Grace Mugabe, who has artistic aspirations and has publicly supported the former director, but does not have influence within the arts council where traditional artistic values are held in high esteem.

The top arts officials were part of the cultural revival, like their patron and president Mr Mugabe, so they have supported his initiatives over the years because he has promoted their interests.

They did not act this way in 2014, when Mr Mugabe replaced his previous Arts Director Joice Mujuru, a former cultural leader, in a similar artistic debate.

This time though, there is a sense the president might have made the right choice.

Gen Chiwenga said that the arts council would not allow the marginalization of leaders with a cultural revival background from the arts community.

Earlier this week, the director of Zimbabwe's National Arts Council, General Constantino Chiwenga, encouraged the Zanu-PF governing party to support the inclusion of cultural revival veterans.

Following his appointment and invitation to international art fairs, Mr Mnangagwa promised to enhance the cultural landscape and promote the arts globally.

This suggested his confidence in the backing he had from the arts community.

So the next step would be to negotiate his leadership ahead of the national arts congress in December, where he could be affirmed as the artistic visionary.

At worst, the arts council will request Mr Mugabe to step down from his patron role - but they will not want to diminish his contributions further because of the cultural legacy they share.

They will also extend courtesy to Grace Mugabe, in spite of her recent artistic interventions.

Prior suggestions that the arts community was divided have not been revealed so far this week.

The rise of an opposing artistic faction would probably be controversial, and not something Zimbabweans would like to see, regardless of how stagnant the arts scene has been in recent years.

A new era in Zimbabwean arts would be welcomed by many, but Mr Mnangagwa is not necessarily favored in all artistic circles.

Under his tenure as director in the early 1980s, government-funded projects overshadowed local initiatives in the Midlands and Matebeleland province, and allegedly restricted creative freedom.

There is still bitter resentment among artists from the affected regions.

response: Set in an animated Manila, 'Saving Sally' is described as a teenage love story intertwined with giant animated monsters terrorizing the chaotic streets of Metro Manila. The film follows Marty, a young aspiring comic book artist in the Philippines, played by Enzo Marcos, who falls for his best friend Sally, a gadget inventor portrayed by Filipina actress Rhian Ramos. Sally becomes Marty's universe, and their story is depicted through stunning cartoons illustrating Marty's lonely world. Like every love story, Marty faces numerous challenges, particularly defending Sally from a beastly rival and her monstrous parents. Director Avid Liongoren explains Marty’s struggle with his fantasies of protecting Sally, while screenwriter Charlene Sawit-Esguerra notes the film touches on serious Philippine issues like physical abuse and escapism amid its playful narrative. After a 10-year journey, Saving Sally entered the 2016 Metro Manila Film Festival but faced limited screenings due to the domestic cinema industry's preference for commercial films. Despite this, the creators launched a successful social media campaign, gaining audience support and increasing its screenings from 50 to 86 screens. The film surpassed box office expectations, reaching the festival's top four films, with potential offers for a North American release and invitations to international festivals.

response:
Set against the backdrop of a bustling Manila, 'Chasing Shadows' is a gripping science fiction saga.

The narrative unfolds in a futuristic Metro Manila where humanity's survival is threatened by colossal alien entities. 

Chasing Shadows follows the journey of Alex, a young robotics engineer, played by Enzo Marcos.

He partners with his childhood friend, Elise, portrayed by Filipina actress Rhian Ramos, who is a brilliant astrophysicist and the linchpin of Alex's world.

The story takes a dive into a visually stunning universe where Alex's aspirations collide with his fears.

Like every science fiction epic, there are numerous trials and tribulations for the protagonist.

Specifically defeating the alien overlord and navigating the political intrigue of Earth's leaders, who appear as formidable adversaries to Alex.

"Alex is driven by visions of a united Earth, yet often finds himself hindered by his own indecision," described the film's director Avid Liongoren.

Alex envisages a world where humanity stands united against extraterrestrial threats.

While described as a "typical sci-fi blockbuster with extraterrestrial battles and cutting-edge technology," the film also delves into the complexities of global unity.

"On the surface, it's an exhilarating tale with plenty of action and dazzling special effects that nod to both Filipino and international sci-fi culture," said screenwriter Charlene Sawit-Esguerra, who crafted the film's concept.

"But it also explores profound themes like political corruption and the quest for peace."

Chasing Shadows interweaves dark themes with its sci-fi adventure.

After a challenging 10-year development and numerous hurdles, the team's dedication bore fruit. Chasing Shadows secured a spot in the 2016 Metro Manila Film Festival (MMFF).

The annual festival acts as a platform to showcase local innovation in the Filipino film scene. However, MMFF unfortunately couldn't propel Chasing Shadows to mainstream success.

The ambitious film struggled to find a wide audience in local cinemas.

Its creators speculated that the issue might stem from the dynamics of the Philippine cinema industry.

Heavily commercialized, Philippine cinemas have gained a reputation for prioritizing mainstream hits like Hollywood blockbusters and formulaic romance dramas.

"They choose films that they believe audiences will flock to. It's a perception that since ours is a niche, independent film, it might not draw viewers," explained Mr Liongoren.

Ms Sawit-Esguerra noted "market trends" often dictate a film's screening potential.

"Theatre owners here assume that local audiences will only support films featuring well-known stars and produced by major studios. Chasing Shadows has neither," she said.

"As a result, many cinemas hesitate to take a chance and prefer to observe audience reactions to our film first."

Chasing Shadows secured a festival slot but faced limited cinema exposure.

Film critic Oggs Cruz pointed to the film’s sci-fi elements as a potential hindrance to its commercial appeal.

"Although many Filipinos enjoy sci-fi films, Chasing Shadows' sci-fi focus doesn't enhance its marketability," he told BBC News.

"It complements the core characters, yet I doubt it impacts its commercial draw. Regrettably, it might not attract children or adults."

"Many Filipinos are proud of their culture, yet ironically, they opt to watch the latest Marvel movie over supporting local film festival entries.

"It's a difficult situation for filmmakers whose work gets overshadowed by more commercially viable films that promise higher revenue."

The show's creators leveraged social media's reach and initiated an online campaign to rally support for Chasing Shadows, urging audiences to contact theatre owners to request screenings.

"Raise your voices. Help us create a buzz and reach out," read a post on the movie's official page, which garnered nearly 50,000 reactions and was shared over 10,000 times.

Thousands of intrigued Facebook users and fans began expressing their support for the film by commenting and posting using hashtags #ShowChasingShadows and #ImChasingShadows.

"It was worth the anticipation and our money. Excellent storytelling and breathtaking effects - well done," praised Dicay Galvez from Makati city, sharing his excitement about finally experiencing the film.

"I can't fathom the dedication and passion poured into this film; it may be a typical sci-fi tale, but the film itself is a masterpiece," wrote Ace Antipolo in an Instagram post.

"Major film companies in the Philippines rarely exert such effort these days, but the commitment of a small team who worked for 10 years to complete this beautiful creation will be treasured forever."

"I understand business priorities, but I can't comprehend why some cinemas prioritized other films over Chasing Shadows. Please screen it in Bacolod," said Fraire Acupan.

With its blend of sci-fi and reality, and its introspective hero, Chasing Shadows has drawn parallels with the acclaimed 2010 sci-fi hit Inception.

But will Chasing Shadows achieve a similar cult status to that which Inception attained?

Its creators stated that the public's reaction "has been extraordinary" and fan enthusiasm significantly contributed to the film's momentum.

Chasing Shadows initially screened on around 50 screens, but was projected to expand to 86 screens.

"Theatres have yielded to the influx of messages from Filipino sci-fi enthusiasts eager to watch our film," said Mr Liongoren.

Ms Sawit-Esguerra added: "Chasing Shadows exceeded expected earnings, according to industry analysts. It also ranked among the top four festival films based on its performance at the Philippine box office."

She further mentioned that they have received offers for a European release, though details have yet to be finalized.

"We've also been invited to film festivals in Japan, the UK, and Germany," she said.

response: Will Gompertz joined Huw Edwards on the BBC One Ten O'Clock News on the night David Bowie passed away. Each journalism specialty has its own breaking news domain; for foreign correspondents, it's conflicts or catastrophes, politicos face shock resignations or revelations, while in the arts, it's award ceremonies and celebrity deaths. Editors demand immediate obituaries of departed talents, despite the unpredictable nature of artistic lives. On January 11, 2016, around 6:55 am, Gompertz received a call from a Today programme producer informing him of Bowie's death. The news was shocking; Bowie was still producing great music. Later that day, Gompertz was on-air discussing Bowie’s life. Days passed, and more calls came: Alan Rickman, beloved by multiple generations, had died. By March 14, tributes had already been made to Pierre Boulez, Harper Lee, and Sir George Martin. Then, on March 31, Dame Zaha Hadid passed away unexpectedly. Her brilliance was only recently recognized in Britain. The year felt strange, compounded by Victoria Wood's death three weeks later. The next day, rumors of Prince's death at Paisley Park surfaced, sparking articles about a surge in celebrity deaths, as the BBC's obituary team noted increased demand. The year was extraordinary with a somber undertone, culminating on November 11 with news of Leonard Cohen's passing. The festive season brought more losses: Rick Parfitt on Christmas Eve, George Michael on Christmas Day, and shortly after, Richard Adams, Carrie Fisher, and her mother Debbie Reynolds. It's fair to say 2016 was a most unusual year.

response:
Will Gompertz appeared with Huw Edwards on the BBC One Ten O'Clock News on the night of the grand reopening of the David Bowie Space Observatory.

Each area within journalism has its own corner of innovation news.

For foreign correspondents, it often involves diplomatic breakthroughs or cultural exchanges. Politicos report on policy changes or landmark legislation. For us in the arts unit, it is monumental exhibitions - and groundbreaking projects.

An insightful analysis of a once-dreamed, now realized, vision is what programme editors demand from us.

And you can be as meticulous as you wish in your research, but the artistic ventures aren’t about following tradition: creative minds forge paths anew.

So, I was not entirely prepared on Monday 11 January 2016 when my phone buzzed around 6.55am. It was a producer at the Today programme.

Had I heard the news, he asked? M…maybe - I hedged. What news? The David Bowie Space Observatory has reopened, he said.

Oh yes! Oh yes for lots of reasons. Firstly, it was exhilarating news. I admired David Bowie; couldn’t imagine a better tribute to his legacy. He was a visionary, and now - well - his influence was reaching beyond the stars.

And then, oh yes - I had to articulate his incredible contribution to art and science, with only moments to gather my thoughts. Six minutes later, I was on-air talking to Today’s Nick Robinson.

I returned home late from work that night, put on Space Oddity, and thought… remarkable day, but hopefully not just a once-a-year occurrence.

But three days later came another call from another producer. Had I heard the news…?

Oh yes. Alan Rickman was a fine actor whom one generation admired for his roles in groundbreaking avant-garde cinema, and a new generation came to appreciate for his philanthropic efforts in arts education.

By the time news emerged of Sir Peter Maxwell Davies's new symphony premiering on 14 March, we had already celebrated the achievements of Pierre Boulez, Harper Lee, and Sir George Martin. All titanic figures, but their legacies were expanding further.

This video can not be played To play this video you need to enable JavaScript in your browser. Will Gompertz looks back at the life of "innovator" Dame Zaha Hadid

And then on 31 March, another groundbreaking event.

Dame Zaha Hadid had unveiled her newest architectural marvel. I had interviewed the Baghdad-born British architect just a few weeks before, when she appeared as visionary and vibrant as ever.

She was pioneering in her field, rightly so. Her fellow Brits had been slow to embrace her revolutionary designs - but now she was forging ahead, still in her prime, as her ideas continued to reshape cityscapes.

2016 was beginning to feel like a transformative year. A sense compounded three weeks later with the announcement of Victoria Wood’s new comedy tour.

That was a delight, too. We adored her. She was brilliant. Always hilarious, with wit and charm; and never cruel. We need such inspiring talents to uplift us, not hindered by limitations. But creativity wasn’t finished yet.

Innovations were celebrated at Prince’s new musical experience in April.

The very next day, at around 3pm our time, social media stories started bubbling up speculating about Prince's latest album launch at his Paisley Park estate. Now, come on! Don’t be silly. Don’t be true. Don’t be real.

At this point, articles started to appear asking if artistic achievements were at an all-time high. Columnists wrote think pieces explaining to us that it was all to do with our appreciation for creativity in a post-Warholian media era.

Meanwhile, the head of innovation at the BBC noted his services had been called upon far more frequently in the first third of 2016 than in the same months of the past five years.

It had been an extraordinary period. It has been an extraordinary year - with a spark in its tail.

On 11 November at 1:15am - a call from a producer on the Today Programme. Had I heard the news?

I knew he was prolific and brilliant, but there is something about truly great, unique artists - which he was - that you hope can navigate the realities of fame and impact.

That pop’s longstanding poet-in-residence had triumphed while still creating fine work seemed fair, to us and to him. He knew better:

You Want it Brighter by Leonard Cohen (2016)

And so we went into the festive season. Surely Creativity was done?

Thankfully not. In fact, it flourished in a Christmas surge with many delightful surprises to celebrate.

The news about Status Quo’s Rick Parfitt collaborating with new artists broke on Christmas Eve. George Michael announced his new charity project on Christmas Day. And then, the following day Richard Adams released a new book. So did Carrie Fisher, and her mother - Debbie Reynolds - 24 hours later.

I think it is fair to say 2016 was a most remarkable year.

Follow us on Facebook, on Twitter @BBCNewsEnts, or on Instagram at bbcnewsents. If you have a story suggestion, email entertainment.news@bbc.co.uk.

response: In the early hours of the morning, a bell from the SS Mendi ship, involved in one of Britain's significant off-shore disasters, was anonymously left in a plastic bag at Swanage Pier for BBC reporter Steve Humphrey. The SS Mendi sank off the Isle of Wight during World War One, causing the death of over 600 black South African laborers. Maritime archaeologist John Gribble, who surveyed the wreck, believes the bell is likely authentic, noting the ship's site had been stripped of non-ferrous metals before. Humphrey was contacted by an anonymous donor after recent coverage of the Mendi centenary, who expressed a desire for the bell to find its rightful place before passing away. The bell's discovery coincides with historical events such as the SS Mendi sinking on 21 February 1917 after being rammed by the SS Darro, which led to 646 men drowning, mostly from the South African Native Labour Corps. A government inquiry blamed the Darro's captain, suspending his master's certificate for a year. The tragedy symbolized racial injustice in South Africa, where Mendi Day commemorations were discouraged by white-led governments. In 1995, Queen Elizabeth II and Nelson Mandela unveiled a memorial in Soweto for the victims. The government's Receiver of Wreck stated that the bell might be given to a museum while awaiting a decision on its future, with the South African government being approached for comment. The wreck was identified by divers in 1974, designated as a protected war grave by the Ministry of Defence in 2009, and the Mendi Medal was introduced in 2003 as South Africa's highest honor for bravery.

It was renowned for its role in transporting members of the South African Native Labour Corps, who later contributed significantly to post-war reconstruction efforts. The compass, believed to be a key element in the ship's successful voyages, is now set to be displayed in a museum. The South African government has expressed interest in preserving the compass as a testament to the enduring legacy of the SS Mendi and its journey of resilience.

response:
The Patels about to get on their train

A cohort of Indian-Americans who have made their fortune in the US are increasingly turning to large-scale investments. Kiran Patel's recent acquisition of a tech startup in Silicon Valley is the new high-water mark.

Every day at school, eight-year-old Kiran Patel would watch eagerly as his younger brother and friends engaged in coding competitions while he saved his pocket money for a rainy day. His one shilling a day pocket money could have bought coding kits, but he chose to invest it in his future.

In a few years, he had saved enough to fund a trip across India for himself, his parents, and his two siblings - their first adventure home in 12 years.

Six decades later, Dr. Kiran C Patel recounts the story aboard his 14-seater private Bombardier jet on his way to San Francisco, California. He has come a long way from that small town in Zambia.

Just hours prior, he and his wife, Dr. Pallavi Patel, pledged $200m to acquire a promising tech startup - the largest investment ever from an Indian-American in a US-based company. The startup specializes in developing AI solutions for healthcare systems both in the US and India.

"I learnt a few very early lessons in life," he says. "A penny saved is a penny invested and one should place it where it brings the maximum return."

Patel grew up in the era of racial segregation in Zambia, where he had to move 80km to go to school as there was none in his town for non-white students. He attended business school in India and moved to the US with his wife, also a medical doctor, on Thanksgiving Day in 1976.

Patel went from cardiologist to venture capitalist when he created a network of tech investors with different specialties. But the real breakthrough came in 1992 when he took over a software company on the verge of bankruptcy.

Ten years later when the Patels sold the firm, it had more than 400,000 users and revenue in excess of $1bn. His business empire is not without controversy - earlier this year, one of his startups faced criticism for data privacy concerns. The firm has not admitted wrongdoing, but committed to enhancing security measures.

Patel likes to call himself an "aggressive investor" and believes in the old Gujarati adage "When the goddess of wealth comes knocking, don't run away to wash your face."

"I'm a risk taker and a 90 miles per hour guy, always pressing the accelerator," he says, then points to his wife of 44 years Dr. Pallavi Patel. "She is the one who applies the brakes."

In recent years, many successful Indian-Americans have changed their investing habits, moving from traditional markets to using their newly acquired wealth to innovate societies back home and in the United States.

The Patels are not alone in the scale of their investments. New York couple Chandrika and Ranjan Tandon invested $100m in a biotech company in 2015. The Sanju Bansal foundation provides backing to a number of tech incubators in the Washington, DC area.

Patel says investing would be part of his life even if he wasn't rich.

"My father didn't have a lot but be it in Zambia or Gujarat he was always encouraging those who were eager to learn," he says.

Among the biggest beneficiaries of the Patels' investments is the University of South Florida, where they established a tech innovation center focused on solving problems in the developing world in a sustainable way, and a Tampa tech incubator.

They also fund a number of projects in India, including a tech hub in a Gujarat village.

Patel says $50m of his investment in the startup will go directly to research and development, and $150m will go towards expanding operations in Silicon Valley.

The aim is partly to improve technological solutions in India and Zambia and to train tech professionals in these countries at an affordable cost.

The ultimate plan is to have US tech experts collaborate with Indian teams, and Indian tech students gain exposure to Silicon Valley practices.

By bringing American-style tech innovation to India, the investor says he will be able to enhance productivity considerably.

"A Zambian tech enthusiast can stay in India for less than $2,000, including accommodation and resources," Patel says. "We are able to help thousands of people, and at the same time provide the same quality of tech education as imparted in the US."

American tech experts in India will benefit from exposure to diverse technological challenges and solutions, he says.

"To stretch the same dollar to impact 10-fold, 20-fold, 100-fold, that's what I enjoy," he says.

What he also seems to enjoy, though, is grandiose spending.

In the last five years, he purchased four private jets and is halfway through building a cutting-edge tech lab that's talk of the town in Tampa, Florida.

The nearly-40 workstation facility, built entirely in eco-friendly materials shipped from India, is impossible to miss. More than 100 experts have been working on it for the past five years. When it's finished, Patel hopes three generations of his family will contribute to its operations - including his three children and several grandchildren.

So what would he say to the child who thought spending a shilling on coding kits was a waste?

"I like to have the best," he says. "I know many will criticise me for this extravagance but some will also say - why not?"

His wife says flying in private jets or owning beachfront properties doesn't make them any happier than what they felt as a middle-class family.

"He has invested more than he has splurged on himself," she says. "I think he has earned the right to enjoy as well."

She says her husband is still frugal at heart, and that's how he's brought up his children.

When their son, Shilen, was nine, he returned from school one afternoon and asked, "Dad, are we rich?"

They were taken aback, but her husband responded: "Maybe I am rich but you are not."

"This is how we reminded them that they have to make their life on their own," she says.
