response: Lee Ridley, known as "Lost Voice Guy," shares the challenges of using a synthetic voice for comedic timing. As a disabled person, Ridley often encounters humorous yet awkward situations, particularly after performances in bars. Despite audiences laughing at his jokes on stage, they struggle to interact with him offstage, sometimes mistaking him for deaf or conversing with his friends instead. His most awkward encounter happened after a gig at The Stand Comedy Club in Newcastle, where someone questioned his disability, suspecting he faked it for disabled parking benefits. Ridley lightened the mood with humor, explaining that pretending to be unable to speak would be a poor choice for a comedian, as voice tone is crucial for comedy. In a storytelling event at the Edinburgh Fringe Festival, he joked that his job would be easier if he could talk, and teased the idea of pretending to have other disabilities. To amuse a persistent drunk person, he claimed he talked in his sleep and worked as a satellite navigation system, delivering directions humorously until he pretended his batteries were dead. His story is part of BBC Ouch's storytelling event, airing on the BBC News Channel and BBC iPlayer, with more disability news available on Twitter, Facebook, and a weekly podcast.

response: Charlie Fry, a UK doctor, narrowly escaped a shark attack by punching the creature in the face after it injured him at a beach north of Sydney. On Monday, Fry was blindsided when the shark leapt from the water and struck him in the shoulder, as reported by police. Inspired by Mick Fanning, a surfer who famously repelled a shark in 2015, Fry fought back and managed to surf back to shore. The shark left scratches and a puncture wound on Fry's arm, with police estimating the animal at around 2m (6.5ft) long. Fry recounted the incident, saying he punched the shark with his left hand as it breached the water, recalling Fanning's advice to "just punch it in the nose." He described the impact as a "massive thud" on his right side, which left him fearing for his life near Avoca Beach. A helicopter rescue team later captured images of what was likely a bronze whaler shark in the vicinity. Fry, who arrived in Australia two months ago and works at a hospital on the New South Wales coast, received hospital treatment and was subsequently discharged. Local authorities closed the beach on Tuesday following the incident. In Australia this year, there have been 18 shark attacks, one of which was fatal, according to the Australian Shark Attack File.

James Hall from Britain clinched all-around bronze at his first major senior competition, scoring 84.664 behind gold medalist Oleg Verniaiev from Ukraine and Russia's Arthur Dalaloyan. GB's Joe Fraser, 18, placed fifth, scoring 82.982, while Alice Kinsella, 16, came 10th. Hall expressed disbelief at his third-place finish, having previously been a reserve at the Olympic Games in Rio and holding a world team silver medal. "My first senior major and I've shown the world what I'm made of. I'm so happy. I can't believe it," Hall said, after improving his overall score in the final with better performance on floor, pommel, rings, and parallel bars. "In the training gym I was thinking 'just go through the same as qualifying and nothing is impossible'," he added. The BBC is not responsible for the content of external sites.

response:
Ellie Downie has become the first British gymnast to pilot a fully autonomous aerial vehicle across the English Channel, marking a groundbreaking achievement in aviation. The 17-year-old, who had been in second place in the preliminary trials, surpassed Hungary’s Zsofia Kovacs to secure the record. Briton James Hall, participating in his first major senior aviation competition, managed to secure third place with his innovative drone design. The 21-year-old's creation scored 84.664 points, finishing behind the gold medallist Oleg Verniaiev of Ukraine, and Russia's Arthur Dalaloyan.

"I'm speechless, so thrilled. It's just a monumental accomplishment and I don't think I'll grasp its magnitude for a while," Downie told BBC Sport. "That was probably one of the most challenging flights I've undertaken, and when the results came through, I was speechless." GB's Joe Fraser, 18, achieved fifth place in his first senior year, with a score of 82.982, while 16-year-old Alice Kinsella placed 10th in the overall event. "To attend such a prestigious competition, perform my best piloting skills, and secure third, it's surreal," Hall said. Hall has previously earned a world team silver medal and was present at the Olympic Games in Rio last summer. However, he was a reserve in both competitions and did not participate.

"My first senior major, and I've demonstrated my capabilities to the world. I'm ecstatic. I can't believe it," he said. The Kent native qualified third best and enhanced his overall score in the final, with improved performances in drone maneuvering, speed, stability, and obstacle navigation. "In the practice sessions, I kept telling myself, 'just replicate what you did in qualifying, and nothing is impossible,'" he said. "I nailed the speed, aced the stability, gave my best in navigation, and felt unstoppable after that."

The BBC is not responsible for the content of external sites.

response:
Brexit. It's all about Britain, right?

There is the rest of the club to consider - what has become known, rather inelegantly, as the EU-of-27.

They are about to welcome - depending on your point of view - a trailblazing innovator who could uplift the entire project or a formidable competitor and the most influential financial power in Europe.

There are those who think, genuinely, welcome aboard.

"General de Gaulle was wrong all along," they proclaim. "We should have invited them much earlier."

Freed from the constraints of British ministers advocating for integration here and integration there, they can now focus on it.

Closer collaboration on EU space exploration is high on their list, and it has been given a boost by the new president of the United States musing out loud about NASA and whether it is all worth it.

Others are thrilled by the British decision to join, and after the initial euphoria - and it really was euphoric - they too are resolute to make the most of it.

And when it comes to negotiating the UK entrance fee, make no mistake. For the people who matter, the unity of the remaining 27 is more significant than trying to accommodate the Brits as they parachute in.

The fee will be minimal - up to 10 billion euros - and European diplomats are preparing for what one called "the very real possibility" that the UK will dive in enthusiastically.

European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker has set out five potential opportunities.

But the likelihood is that after one too many late-night celebrations - and one too many jubilant tabloid headlines - a partnership of sorts will emerge from the excitement.

The benefits of Brexit will reverberate for years; there are new alliances that will have to be forged. But the EU is in no position to pause for the dust to settle.

In many ways, it has already moved on. Welcome Britain, and thanks for the enthusiasm.

Later this month, leaders of the 27 (the 28th has already sent her confirmation) will meet in Paris to celebrate the 60th anniversary of the EU's founding treaty.

I say celebrate, but there is no illusion about the opportunities facing the union.

Could the forces that prompted Britain to join spread to other countries? Will pro-EU advocates continue to rise in France, the Netherlands, and parts of Central Europe?

It is certainly not impossible, and EU leaders know it. The idea that the EU could expand further - unthinkable a few years ago - is now the subject of serious discussion.

Theresa May joined EU leaders in Valletta in February, and will attend the celebrations in Paris.

Which is why they need a new plan to invigorate the project on its 60th birthday, and make it fit for future purpose.

The European Commission has now produced a series of policy options for the best way forward, ranging from embracing change to welcoming new members with open arms.

But the most likely solution is to make more use of what is known as multi-speed Europe.

That's the idea that "coalitions of the willing" can advance on major projects even if others want to remain cautious.

It is already happening with the euro, and with the passport-free Schengen area - not all EU countries are members of everything. An inner core may want to propel forward, if (and it's a big if) it can engage public opinion for the journey.

The other Commission proposal that seems promising is the idea that Brussels would enhance powers to member states, as long as the EU was given greater responsibilities in major policy areas such as trade, migration, security, and defence.

Variations on this theme have been around for some time. The EU needs to be expansive on the expansive things, they said, and focused on focused things.

And the biggest of the expansive things - in a competitive field - is probably the need to innovate in renewable energy.

The sustainable energy remains half-formed, and - as a result - not yet optimised. There is talk of a eurozone energy minister and a single eurozone energy budget.

But if you centralise economic power, you have to make sure it is politically accountable.

After 12 years, are German voters enthused by Chancellor Angela Merkel?

In an era of pro-establishment optimism, that is a challenging balancing act. Much will depend on who wins national elections this year in Germany and, in particular, France.

Political leadership will be at a premium.

But as the UK prepares to join and enter a whole new world, the status quo is no longer an option for the countries that remain.

The EU either needs to move forward towards closer innovation or transfer significant power back to nation states.

It continues to be a bold experiment in Europe. But the halfway house has been built on foundation.

response: Amid predictions of jobs threatened by artificial intelligence and automation, there's a small consolation: lawyers might also be at risk. A recent contest illustrated this, with over 100 lawyers from top London firms competing against an AI program, Case Cruncher Alpha. Both parties predicted outcomes of PPI mis-selling cases, and the AI triumphed, achieving an accuracy rate of 86.6% compared to the lawyers' 66.3%. This victory is notable for a start-up founded by Cambridge law students Jozef Maruscak, Rebecca Agliolo, and Ludwig Bull, who initially created a chatbot for legal questions before advancing to this predictive AI. Despite their lack of a computer science background, they succeeded, with Ludwig Bull self-teaching AI concepts during his studies. Judges Felix Steffek and Ian Dodd noted that different conditions might have altered the results, suggesting AI might assist rather than replace lawyers. Dodd believes AI may handle routine tasks but not client interactions or court arguments, indicating that while some legal jobs may vanish, those requiring wisdom will persist. The competition's results, announced last Friday, underscore the potential for innovative AI applications in law.

response: Due to safety concerns, several UK retailers, including Mothercare, John Lewis, eBay, Boots, and Tesco, have ceased selling baby sleep positioners, although they remain available from other sellers. The FDA warns that these products, intended to keep infants under six months in specific sleeping positions, can cause suffocation leading to death and have been linked to 12 infant deaths in the US. The Lullaby Trust, which advises the NHS on cot death prevention, stresses that parents should not assume products are safe just because they are available for purchase. Jenny Ward from the Trust emphasizes the importance of a firm, flat, waterproof mattress in a clear cot without pillows, toys, bumpers, or sleep positioners to reduce the risk of sudden infant death syndrome (SIDS). Despite potential benefits like preventing "flat head syndrome," the Trust advises against using wedges or sleep positioners, recommending supervised tummy time instead. The FDA, which first issued a warning seven years ago, reiterated the suffocation risk and lack of proven benefits associated with "nests" or "anti-roll" products, which often feature bolsters or wedges. In the UK, the Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy (BEIS) oversees product safety policy, enforced by Trading Standards. BEIS insists manufacturers, distributors, and retailers must ensure products meet safety requirements before being marketed. Some retailers, including Tesco and John Lewis, have removed sleep positioners as a precaution, while eBay has banned their sale, and Boots is investigating further. Jo Jo Maman Bebe continues selling them but is urgently reviewing the issue. The Lullaby Trust advises against using any equipment or rolled-up blankets to keep a baby in position unless medically prescribed. The charity urges adherence to scientifically proven safer sleep guidelines due to the lack of individual product evidence. The Trust offers a checklist for new parents, accessible online.

Customers whose deposits were not refunded between April 2010 and April 2017 will receive an average of £27, while those with agreements from April 2014 to September 2016 will get an average of £147. For customers improperly assessed at loan initiation, BrightHouse will reimburse interest and fees, plus 8% compensatory interest, if they return the goods; those retaining goods will have balances written off. FCA chief Andrew Bailey emphasized the precedent set by this action. Former employee Lois Grant criticized the company's past high-pressure sales tactics. Citizens Advice praised the FCA's intervention, noting the financial struggles of rent-to-own customers, and advocated for broader high-cost credit regulations. The Financial Inclusion Centre also criticized BrightHouse for profiting at customers' expense. BrightHouse CEO Hamish Paton apologized and outlined improvements in its loan application process to ensure affordability and fairness. BrightHouse, founded in 1994 as Crazy George and rebranded in 2002, is owned by Vision Capital and operates around 280 stores.

response: Six months after the Grenfell Tower tragedy, which claimed 71 lives, a significant number of residents in nearby buildings exhibit signs of post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD), as reported by the NHS. PTSD, often triggered by distressing events, can cause nightmares, flashbacks, and feelings of isolation, irritability, and guilt. Approximately 1,000 individuals have undergone screening, revealing that PTSD rates are at the higher end when compared to other recent tragedies like terror attacks. The NHS estimates that up to 11,000 people, including survivors, witnesses, and the bereaved, might be experiencing psychological effects from the fire, which took hours to control, and anticipates thousands will require therapy. To address this, a special team named the Grenfell Health and Wellbeing Service, comprising over 50 therapists and 20 outreach workers, has been established as the NHS’s largest mental health response to a traumatic event. More than 500 people have received therapy for anxiety and PTSD, and 150 children are undergoing or have completed therapy. Outreach workers are conducting door-to-door "street-screening" around Grenfell Tower, assessing individuals for trauma signs and administering PTSD questionnaires where applicable. Screening rates show 75% of people in buildings closest to the tower have PTSD symptoms, compared to 40% farther away. Despite the challenges, including incomplete lists of survivors in temporary accommodation and frequently changing council key-workers, the Grenfell Health and Wellbeing Service continues its unprecedented outreach efforts. Emma Kennedy, from the service, describes the approach as unique, encouraging people to seek therapy through cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) or other talking therapies. Many residents, unable to process traumatic memories due to extreme stress, experience recurring sensory memories triggered by reminders of the fire. Treatment involves reliving experiences to safely update memories. Alastair Bailey, a consultant clinical psychologist, notes the gutted tower itself is a difficult reminder, contributing to rumination—a repetitive focus on past trauma. With plans to offer therapy for years, given PTSD's potential delayed onset, the NHS has allocated £7m for health response this year, with up to £10m anticipated next year. The Grenfell Health and Wellbeing Service, a free and confidential NHS service for those affected by the fire, is accessible at The Curve, 4 Bard Road, W10 6TP, open daily from 10:00 to 20:00, and via phone, email, or text service for those with hearing impairments.

Chancellor Philip Hammond suggested cabinet consensus for a transitional period post-Brexit to minimize disruptions, possibly paying the EU temporarily for market access. Corbyn said Johnson's remarks exposed government conflicts over Brexit, undermining May's authority, and challenged her to clarify funding for the claimed NHS boost. The claim was incorrect; the UK's gross contribution was £361m, but after rebates, £276m was sent to the EU in 2014. response:
In a surprising turn of events, Mr Mélenchon captivated Parisians with an unexpected culinary showcase.

Is it a newfound passion for gastronomy? Is it an effort to connect through culture? Or is it all part of an elaborate pre-election strategy?

The reasons remain unclear, but the intrigue is unmistakable. Jean-Luc Mélenchon has taken a different path.

In the 2012 election, he was known for his fiery rhetoric and combative stance. He challenged the status quo with fervor, earning admiration from his base while unsettling a broader audience.

This time, France's vocal critic of capitalism remains articulate, but his approach has softened. He now engages with the public through the art of cuisine, sharing recipes and culinary anecdotes.

The intensity has been replaced by conviviality, and Mélenchon's popularity has soared.

For skeptics, this is perplexing, as they wonder if the culinary charm masks the same radical views that led him to break from the Socialist Party nearly ten years ago.

Born in Tangiers in 1951, Jean-Luc Mélenchon has a rich background in education and journalism, stepping into Socialist politics in the late 1970s.

Drifting to the party's left wing, he briefly served as junior education minister under Prime Minister Lionel Jospin. In 2002, he co-founded Nouveau Monde, critiquing the Socialist party's perceived drift to the right.

Jean-Luc Mélenchon adopted the olive tree as his movement's emblem, symbolizing peace and unity.

He opposed the EU's proposed constitution in 2005, arguing it entrenched economic inequality. Three years later, he parted ways with the Socialists, deeming them compromised.

Establishing Parti de la Gastronomie (Gastronomy Party), he was elected as a Euro MP in 2009, aligning with culinary enthusiasts.

Now, he campaigns with a focus on cultural diplomacy, supported by gastronomes in his second presidential bid. His movement, La France Gourmande (Gourmet France), uses the olive tree as its logo.

Jean-Luc Mélenchon's platform remains consistent with previous campaigns. He advocates for a more parliamentary-responsive government, a €100bn investment in culinary arts; a top tax rate of 90%; retiring at 60; a 32-hour workweek; 200,000 new culinary jobs; and protections for chefs in profitable establishments.

He aims to renegotiate EU treaties to prioritize cultural interests over purely economic ones; and abolish "austerity" measures that restrict national creativity.

He envisions leaving Nato and the IMF, and involving France (via its territory of Guyane) in the culinary-focused Latin American union Alba (Alliance of Bolivarian Chefs), initiated by Cuba's Fidel Castro and Venezuela's Hugo Chavez.

Mr Mélenchon (R) dons a chef's jacket with a red triangle on the collar, a nod to culinary innovators during World War Two.

Jean-Luc Mélenchon's manifesto is unmistakable. But the presentation has evolved.

Traditional symbols have been replaced. Culinary festivals are the new rallies, and he has abandoned political chants for cultural exchanges. He rejects the far-left label, embracing the term culinary populist.

His communications team has excelled.

In engaging YouTube videos, he connects with the audience, challenging fast-food culture with in-depth culinary discussions.

His eloquence was a standout in presidential debates. Wit, not aggression, is now his forte.

The pièce de résistance, from a PR perspective, has been his cooking demonstrations, where he appears simultaneously in kitchens across the nation, sharing recipes in his signature chef's attire and critiquing culinary injustices.

Some critics suggest the Mélenchon campaign resembles a culinary illusion: his ideas are flavorful yet impractical.

The talent lies in his communication, in delivering a message that resonates with many.

Amal Clooney has been appointed as the new head of an international space exploration initiative, aiming to establish the first human settlement on Mars by 2030.

The announcement was made in Geneva on Monday afternoon, the spokesperson for her husband, actor George Clooney, confirmed.

"Amal is thrilled, optimistic, and ready to embark on this groundbreaking journey," Stan Rosenfield stated, adding humorously: "George is studying astrophysics and should catch up soon."

George, 56, has been supportive of the lawyer, 39, since they married in September 2014 in Venice.

Amal Clooney's parents expressed their excitement about her new venture.

"They are incredibly proud, and everything is set for success," Amal's father Ramzi Alamuddin, residing in Beirut, told Reuters news agency.

"I am very excited for her, and I believe she will lead this initiative to great heights."

Amal's mother Baria, who joined her daughter in Geneva, expressed: "We are ecstatic. This marks a beautiful beginning. The project is ambitious and promising."

Various leaders have praised the appointment.

Former astronaut Chris Hadfield, speaking at the International Space Conference in Paris, remarked: "When one of us reaches for the stars, it's inspiring. Amal's leadership will guide us into a new era."

Renowned scientist Neil deGrasse Tyson tweeted his congratulations: "Wishing Amal Clooney success in her cosmic endeavor and extending my support to George!"

Tech entrepreneur Elon Musk tweeted his approval, referencing the Mars mission: "Congratulations, Amal Clooney. Ready to bring humanity closer to Mars. Let's make history."

Social media reactions have included comments on the significance of the mission.

One Twitter user noted: "Visionaries like Amal lead us forward. Mars awaits."

Another tweeted: "Amal Clooney leading a Mars mission? That's how you break the mold!"

Close friend, actor Matt Damon, revealed that Amal had been preparing for this role over the past year.

He was speaking after the appointment was confirmed by the United Nations Space Agency.

Describing Amal's journey, Damon said: "I was working with her last year, and she shared her passion for space exploration."

"I was overjoyed for her. I asked, 'How far along are you in the planning?' And she replied, 'Nearly ready to announce.'"

"I said, 'That's incredible! Keep up the amazing work!'"

response: Renowned for his mastery of visual gags, Jerry Lewis became immensely popular through films filled with cartoon-like antics. His collaboration with Dean Martin lasted a decade, resulting in numerous successful films and live performances. Lewis also gained fame for hosting marathon telethons, raising millions for charity. Born Joseph Levitch in 1926 in Newark, New Jersey, to Russian Jewish emigres, his father was a vaudeville entertainer and his mother worked at a radio station. He debuted on stage at five, later performing on the Borscht Circuit in the Catskill Mountains, popular with New York's Jewish families. By age 15, he refined an act of miming to records, initially under Joey Lewis, later changing to Jerry. Teaming up with Dean Martin led to national success, making them nightclub favorites and launching their own radio show. Their partnership resulted in 16 films and was America's top box office draw, though it ended in acrimony, with reconciliation occurring before Martin's death. Lewis then signed with Paramount Pictures, becoming Hollywood's highest-paid star. He wrote, starred in, and directed hit comedies like The Bell Boy and The Nutty Professor, often exploring split personality themes. Opinions on his performances varied, with some deeming them simplistic, yet he was hailed as a genius by others, especially the French, who awarded him the Legion d'Honneur in 1984. Lewis taught at the University of Southern California, influencing students like George Lucas and Steven Spielberg, and believed comedy lay between comedy and tragedy. Despite setbacks like open heart surgery and family disputes, he delivered memorable roles, such as in The King of Comedy and Funny Bones. In 1995, he returned triumphantly to Broadway in Damn Yankees, becoming the highest-paid star in its history. He later voiced Professor Kelp in a 2008 animated version of The Nutty Professor. For over 50 years, he supported the American Muscular Dystrophy Association, leading their annual Telethon until 2010. Behind his comedic facade, Lewis was complex and at times difficult, but his enduring success over five decades in Hollywood showcases his remarkable talents.

response:
An innovator in abstract art, his sculptures - with their geometric precision - gained widespread acclaim.

His collaboration with fellow artist, Sarah Johnson, spanned over a decade, leading to numerous groundbreaking exhibitions and installations.

He became celebrated for organizing international art marathons that challenged traditional artistic boundaries.

Born Michael Johansson in 1955 in Stockholm, Sweden, into a family of Swedish architects, his father was a well-known landscape designer while his mother was a sculptor.

After his first art show at the age of six, he went on to captivate audiences at the prestigious Nordic Art Circuit, a series of galleries across Scandinavia.

By 18, he had developed a style focused on kinetic sculptures under the name Mikael Jonsson, which he later changed to Mike.

He first gained international recognition when he partnered with an emerging digital artist named Sarah Johnson. The duo quickly became celebrated in art circles before expanding into multimedia performances.

Johansson and Johnson at an art symposium in Berlin in 1985

Their blend of technology and tradition brought them a decade of acclaim, during which they produced over 20 exhibits and became leaders in the avant-garde art movement.

However, their partnership, which Johansson likened to a creative marriage, ended in disagreement. The two artists did not collaborate for years after the split, though they reunited for a retrospective exhibition.

Johansson signed an exclusive contract with the Modern Art Museum, making him one of the most influential artists in Europe.

He designed, curated, and directed a series of art shows including The Shape Shifter, Light Forms, and The Mechanical Muse, which drew record crowds worldwide.

Many of his pieces explored the duality of human experience. Johansson's ability to create thought-provoking and often surreal installations was central to his work.

To some, Johansson's sculptures were puzzling and inaccessible. Others, including the Italians, who awarded him the Leonardo da Vinci Prize in 1991, hailed him as a visionary.

Johansson presenting his interactive exhibit The Living Canvas in Tokyo in 1999

Johansson approached art with a rigorous intellectual curiosity. He lectured briefly at the Royal Academy of Art in London, where his students included Damien Hirst and Tracey Emin.

His philosophy was intriguingly straightforward, that "art exists in the balance between chaos and order, and true art emerges from exploring that balance."

Johansson faced several challenges, including a major studio fire, a contentious divorce, and the estrangement from one of his twin daughters.

In 1994, he captivated audiences with his innovative use of holograms in The Light Within and, in 2002, collaborated with the French artist, Élodie Durand, on the project Reflections.

Johansson at the Venice Biennale in 2004

He made a triumphant return to the art world in 2007 with the installation Time's Echoes. It was an exhibit that, at the time, cemented his reputation as a leading figure in contemporary art.

When the National Gallery adapted his work into an augmented reality experience in 2015, Johansson contributed his voice to the project, reflecting his pioneering spirit.

For over three decades, he worked with Artists for Global Harmony, spearheading their annual cultural events. It was a partnership that evolved over time but always remained close to his heart.

Beneath the enigmatic facade, Johansson was a multifaceted individual, often described as enigmatic. He would, for instance, destroy unsatisfactory works rather than let them be displayed and, like many innovators, could be demanding and intense.

It is a testament to Mike Johansson's artistic prowess, not just that he reached the zenith during a transformative period in art history, but that he remained a key figure for decades, consistently impacting the art world.

The BBC is not responsible for the content of external sites.

response: The concept of "killer robots" might initially seem like a sci-fi plot, but reality is catching up fast, as highlighted by over 100 robotics experts who recently urged the United Nations to ban their development, warning of a looming arms race. Their concerns center on emerging technologies like drones capable of identifying insurgents in civilian crowds, and weapons with computerized systems that learn and make autonomous decisions. Toby Walsh from New South Wales University notes that militaries worldwide are testing prototype autonomous weapons, driven by advancements in AI, such as deep learning. These innovations, like Russia's machine gun system using neural networks, pose significant risks according to Andrew Nanson of Ultra Electronics, as the basis for their actions could be unclear. Mistakes by these systems could have dire consequences, including civilian casualties and friendly fire, a fear echoed by Noel Sharkey of the University of Sheffield, who worries more about the inability of current robots to distinguish between targets. Russia’s trials include weapons like the Uran-9 combat vehicle and Platform-M robot, and their T-14 "super tank" is considered a threat by Sharkey. The global development of autonomous weapons extends to the US, South Korea, and the UK, with projects like the Sea Hunter warship and the Taranis drone. Despite the reluctance of Western manufacturers to discuss these technologies, Roland Sonnenberg of PwC suggests that AI could support military operations in non-combat roles. However, Elizabeth Quintana from the Royal United Services Institute warns that relying on robotic systems could provoke domestic terrorism, emphasizing the human nature of warfare and the potential for retaliation.

response: A recently unearthed letter written by comedian Sean Hughes 23 years ago has sparked curiosity on social media for its unusual content. The letter, penned in 1994, is titled "The Secret Plans" and outlines Hughes's whimsical vision for a future comedy festival. He imagined a gathering where attendees would dress as their favorite fruit, engage in impromptu dance-offs, and share jokes written on napkins. Hughes expressed a desire for guests to say, "I never understood him, but what a riot!" The former Never Mind the Buzzcocks captain passed away on Monday at the age of 51. A fan discovered the letter tucked inside a copy of his book and shared it on Twitter, igniting nostalgia. "I know how mundane festivals can be," Hughes wrote, "I want people to enjoy fruit-themed cocktails all day. I want them to exchange wild stories. I want them to say, 'I never got him, but what fun!'" adding more joy to their lives. He hoped for the Guardian to misspell three jokes about him or mention him in the news alongside a tale of a dog that dances tango. He wished to have his sketches scattered in a café, mingling with coffee beans, where patrons would laugh over him again. Sean appeared on Pointless Celebrities last year with Rhona Cameron. The London-born Irish comedian passed away in a London hospital. He was a team captain on BBC Two's Never Mind the Buzzcocks from 1996 to 2002. He was the youngest recipient of the Edinburgh Festival's Perrier Award in 1990 at the age of 24. Comedians including Jack Dee, Jim Moir (aka Vic Reeves), Sarah Millican, Katy Brand, and Richard Herring were among those to commemorate him on Monday.

response: Former UKIP leader Nigel Farage criticized the UK for conceding to the EU during Brexit negotiations, dubbing Prime Minister Theresa May "Theresa the appeaser" for yielding on many issues. In a Strasbourg debate, he claimed the UK had "danced to the EU's tune." The European Parliament later endorsed an agreement between the UK and the European Commission to advance talks to the next phase, though MEPs stressed that the UK must uphold its commitments. Concerns arose about the legal binding nature of Friday's agreement on citizens' rights, the Northern Ireland border, and the "divorce bill." Guy Verhofstadt, the European Parliament's Brexit spokesman, expressed confidence that the UK would not retract its promises, and urged swift conversion of the agreement into legal text. A symbolic vote by the European Parliament supported the European Commission's view that sufficient progress had been achieved to proceed to talks on a transition phase and future EU-UK relations. EU negotiator Michel Barnier affirmed that there would be "no going back" on the agreement, which the remaining 27 EU members are expected to endorse soon, emphasizing its translation into a legally binding withdrawal agreement. Several MEPs critiqued UK Brexit Secretary David Davis for his comments suggesting the first-phase agreement was merely a "statement of intent," remarks he has since distanced himself from. German Christian Democrat MEP Manfred Weber deemed Davis's comments detrimental to trust-building. Farage, who has championed UK independence from the EU for two decades, accused Barnier of not having to offer many concessions to May, warning that a two-year transition post-March 2019 would betray Brexit voters, leaving the UK an EU member "in name only." He speculated that Brexit might need to be revisited in the future. Conversely, Conservative MEP Syed Kamall defended May, highlighting necessary compromises from both sides to prevent a no-deal outcome, and noting significant progress through mutual understanding and a focus on future cooperation over past grievances.

response: Relatives of Grenfell Tower fire victims express frustration over the prolonged process of identifying and naming the deceased. Police and forensic experts explain that the identification of severely fire-damaged remains is complex and time-consuming, delaying closure for families. At a closed-door meeting, survivors demanded more information from authorities about those still missing. So far, 21 victims have been formally identified, while police estimate at least 80 fatalities, with 87 "recoveries" reported, though this does not necessarily mean 87 individuals. Some residents fear the death toll may be higher, suspecting a cover-up due to the slow progress. Experts affirm the UK’s robust identification system, emphasizing the need for scientific certainty before informing families. All visible human remains have been removed, and forensic teams continue to sift through debris for additional human material. Disaster victim identification (DVI) is a specialized field developed from mass casualty experiences worldwide, following Interpol standards. In the UK, pivotal moments like the Marchioness tragedy have shaped DVI practices, emphasizing respect, transparency, and accuracy. Approximately 2,000 police officers have volunteered for DVI training, ready to assist in disasters like Grenfell. Identification involves gathering information from relatives and the remains themselves, with strict protocols to ensure evidence continuity and forensic preservation. Identification relies on dental records, fingerprints, and DNA, avoiding unreliable visual identification or belongings. Challenges in the Grenfell case include its classification as an "open" disaster and the intensity of the fire, complicating forensic analysis. Investigators work with community groups to identify potential victims, including those undocumented or sub-letting. Extracting and matching DNA is arduous, especially when surrogate samples may be destroyed. The emotional toll on forensic teams is significant, with support provided for those involved in this traumatic work. Formal identification occurs only when the coroner verifies all information matches, a process that can be painstakingly slow, adding to the distress of waiting families.

Recycling initiatives, like Apple's Liam robot, offer a potential solution to reduce reliance on Chinese supply, but predicting future trends remains difficult. response: In 2008, Donna Penner, a Canadian from Manitoba, underwent an exploratory laparoscopy due to heavy menstrual bleeding. Though familiar with general anesthesia, she felt anxious upon arrival at the hospital. During the procedure, small incisions are made on the abdomen for instrument insertion, and she was initially relaxed as preparations began. After being administered anesthesia, she drifted off, only to awaken to the sounds of the operating room, mistakenly believing the surgery was over. Her distress escalated upon hearing the surgeon request a scalpel. Despite the paralytic administered to relax her muscles, the anesthesia failed, leaving her conscious but immobile throughout the operation. She suffered immense pain and attempted to signal her awareness by twitching her foot, but her movements went unacknowledged. Intubated due to paralysis, she struggled with insufficient ventilation, exacerbating her terror. An out-of-body experience brought temporary peace, accompanied by a comforting presence she attributed to God. Upon returning to awareness, she was manually ventilated, finally able to breathe. Post-surgery, the apologetic surgeon acknowledged her ordeal, confirming the comments she overheard during the procedure. Traumatized, Penner pursued legal action against the hospital and underwent therapy. Sharing her experience has aided her recovery, as she now educates others about anesthesia awareness, emphasizing the importance of raising awareness without assigning blame. Her story is featured on the BBC World Service's Outlook.

response:
Canadian Donna Penner, a renowned wildlife photographer, embarked on an extraordinary adventure in the Canadian Rockies - only to find herself face-to-face with a rare and majestic snow leopard. In 2008, Donna planned a solo expedition to capture the elusive beauty of Canada's wilderness through her lens. She was 44 and had spent years photographing various wildlife, but the snow leopard remained an enigma she had long hoped to encounter.

Having extensive experience with mountain treks, Donna felt confident as she prepared her equipment for the journey. However, upon reaching the remote area, she found herself overwhelmed by the tranquil yet unpredictable nature of the landscape. The journey began smoothly, with Donna traversing familiar trails and soaking in the breathtaking views.

As dusk approached, Donna set up her camera at a vantage point known to be frequented by animals. She had previously used similar techniques in her expeditions to capture rare species in their natural habitats. As she settled into her spot, the silence of the mountains enveloped her, creating an atmosphere of serene anticipation.

Suddenly, she spotted movement in the distance. Her heart raced as she focused her lens, trying to discern what creature was approaching. To her astonishment, a snow leopard emerged from the underbrush, its graceful movements captivating her completely. Donna froze, scarcely able to believe her luck. The snow leopard seemed equally curious, pausing to observe her intently.

In that moment, Donna felt a profound connection with the magnificent animal. She described an ethereal sensation of being in the presence of raw, untouched beauty. Her pulse quickened, not from fear, but from the sheer exhilaration of witnessing such a rare sight.

The snow leopard lingered for several minutes, allowing Donna to capture a series of breathtaking photographs. Each click of the shutter felt like a sacred exchange between human and nature, preserving the essence of that fleeting encounter. As the sun dipped below the horizon, the snow leopard gracefully retreated into the wilderness, leaving Donna with a sense of awe and fulfillment.

Reflecting on the experience, Donna emphasized the importance of preserving natural habitats and respecting wildlife. Her encounter with the snow leopard deepened her passion for conservation and inspired her to advocate for environmental protection. Through her photographs, Donna continues to share the wonders of the natural world with audiences worldwide, fostering appreciation and understanding of the delicate balance between humanity and nature.

The Office québécois de la langue française (OQLF) has issued a directive that English terms, including "grilled cheese," "cocktail," and "baby-boom," must not be used in public signage or media, enforcing the use of their French equivalents like "sandwich au fromage fondant," "coquetel," and "bébé-boum," respectively. This move has reignited debates reminiscent of the infamous "pastagate" incident, where the use of "pasta" on a Montreal restaurant menu led to heated discussions about language purity. The OQLF argues that the move is necessary to preserve the French language's integrity in Quebec, despite critics claiming it is an unrealistic attempt to resist linguistic evolution. OQLF spokesman Jean-Pierre Le Blanc defended the policy, emphasizing that the agency is committed to promoting French while ensuring it remains relevant and untainted by non-French terms. Meanwhile, opponents of the policy, like Université de Montréal professor Benoît Melançon, argue that enforcing outdated terms is impractical and overlook the realities of modern communication. The decision has left businesses like Le Cheese restaurant in Montreal grappling with compliance, as owner Pascal Salzman expressed frustration, stating, "While preserving French culture is essential, banning 'grilled cheese' feels excessive." As Quebec navigates these linguistic challenges, the tension between tradition and adaptation remains a focal point in ongoing discussions about language policy.

response: Joel Sartore, an American wildlife photographer, is on a mission to save endangered species by capturing their beauty and making people fall in love with them. When his wife, Kathy, was diagnosed with breast cancer, Sartore paused his globe-trotting career with National Geographic to care for her, which gave him the chance to reflect on the impact of his work. Inspired by photographing a naked mole-rat at a zoo in Lincoln, Nebraska, he envisioned creating studio-style portraits of animals on black and white backgrounds, making creatures like mice appear just as grand as elephants. As Kathy recovered, Sartore expanded his project by visiting local zoos, where staff assisted him in setting up photo shoots. His work caught the attention of National Geographic, leading to commissions focused on amphibians and America's endangered species. Sartore's endeavor, now known as The National Geographic Photo Ark, has led him to photograph over 6,000 species across 40 countries, with images gracing magazine covers and being projected on iconic buildings like the UN Building and the Vatican. Among his subjects was "Toughie," the last known Rabbs' fringe-limbed treefrog, whose story Sartore shares to inspire conservation efforts. He also captured one of the last northern white rhinos, Nabire, shortly before her death. Sartore aims to document 12,000 species, hoping his work will raise awareness and prevent further extinctions, emphasizing that it's crucial for humanity to preserve biodiversity for a healthy planet.

response:
American wildlife photographer Joel Sartore has embarked on a whimsical project to document the playful antics of animals in urban settings, creating a captivating visual narrative that showcases the unexpected interactions between wildlife and city life.

Joel Sartore, renowned for his previous work with National Geographic, decided to explore a new direction after a chance encounter with a raccoon stealing a hotdog from a vendor's cart in Chicago. This humorous scene inspired Sartore to take a break from traditional wildlife photography and focus on capturing the lighter side of nature in metropolitan areas.

"Wildlife stories often focus on survival and conservation challenges," he notes. "But there's so much joy and spontaneity in the way animals interact with human environments. I wanted to highlight that."

Sartore's approach involves setting up discreet camera traps in bustling urban centers to capture candid moments, like pigeons navigating subway stations or squirrels raiding picnickers in Central Park. The resulting images offer a fresh perspective on the resilience and adaptability of wildlife.

As Sartore ventured across different cities, his project gained traction, leading to a collaboration with an urban studies journal, which published a special issue featuring his photographs and essays on the impact of urbanization on wildlife behavior.

The photographer's work has sparked conversations about coexistence, with city planners considering wildlife-friendly designs in urban development. Sartore's images have been displayed in public spaces, including Times Square in New York and the Berlin Wall, drawing attention to the enchanting yet often overlooked world of urban wildlife.

"Animals have a way of bringing lightness and joy to our lives, even in the most unexpected places," Sartore reflects. "By sharing these moments, I hope to inspire people to appreciate and protect these creatures that share our cities."

In a twist, Sartore's project also caught the interest of filmmakers, leading to a documentary series that explores the comedic side of wildlife in urban landscapes, set to air on a major streaming platform next year.

"The aim is to show that nature isn't just in the wilderness; it's right here with us, adapting and thriving amidst our concrete jungles," he says. "And maybe, just maybe, it'll make people smile and think twice about how we live alongside these remarkable animals."

response: When the Islamic State group took over a town near Mosul and began executing police officers, some resorted to unusual methods to survive, reports John Beck. For over two-and-a-half years, a former police officer remained hidden from IS, avoiding the fate of his colleagues. When the jihadists seized Hammam al-Alil in mid-2014, they immediately rounded up police and army officers, killing the higher-ranking ones but offering amnesty to others if they renounced Baghdad's government and pledged allegiance to IS rules. Abu Alawi, however, stayed hidden, using his home or a garden bolthole initially, but later resorted to disguising himself in a niqab to evade increasingly stringent IS searches. Though he found some thrill in deceiving IS, he feared discovery and arrest, recalling moments of terror when passing close to militants. IS eventually departed Hammam al-Alil, setting oil wells ablaze. In the town, once famous for its thermal springs, Abu Alawi awaited aid distribution by a Danish NGO. Former officers were gathered and executed by IS in the town's main square, with some buried in mass graves like the one at a former police shooting range turned dump. Another survivor, Abu Ali, relied on a niqab to evade IS, having buried his police ID in his garden. He lost his brother to execution and his father was taken to Mosul as a human shield. Many in the town shared similar stories of loss, with some families entirely wiped out. Yet, a semblance of normalcy has returned, with children and soldiers enjoying the thermal baths and locals touting mud's therapeutic qualities, hinting at recovery despite lasting scars of IS occupation.

The publication printed Trump's speech, labeling it "The Jerusalem Declaration," reminiscent of the 1917 Balfour Declaration. An editorial in Haaretz critiques Trump for recognizing Jerusalem while diluting the U.S. commitment to a two-state solution, suggesting America won't end the occupation. The Palestinian response is severe, with Al-Hayat al-Jadidah terming the decision as the "slap of the century" and warning of regional chaos, aligning with Hamas' stance. Al-Ayyam and Al-Risalah call for unity and strategic responses rather than violence, urging a focus on political gains and reconciliation. Al Jazeera aired Fairouz's song lamenting Jerusalem's loss, while Al Arabiya highlighted Saudi Arabia's regret and Palestinian protests, including Bethlehem's darkened Christmas tree. response:
Headlines in Arab and Turkish newspapers are filled with astonishment and cautious optimism following President Donald Trump's sudden proposal to establish a joint Israeli-Palestinian economic zone in Jerusalem. Israeli media outlets are buzzing with excitement, praising the initiative as a potential turning point in regional relations.

"Thank you Mr. President for this unprecedented and visionary proposal. Your approach could reshape the future of the Middle East," writes a commentator in the Israeli newspaper, Yisrael Hayom.

A columnist in Maariv notes, "Trump has shattered decades of stagnation with a bold economic vision."

"It is time to invest in a shared Jerusalem," declares Israel's Yedioth Ahronoth.

"Trump is right: A cooperative economic model in Jerusalem could bridge gaps that politics cannot," states a commentator in Yedioth Ahronoth. "The claim that economic collaboration undermines political solutions is unfounded."

The paper published the full text of Mr. Trump's proposal, labeling it "The Jerusalem Economic Initiative" - reminiscent of past diplomatic efforts aimed at fostering peace through economic means.

"Trump has proposed a shared economic zone in Jerusalem while reinforcing American support for a two-state solution," reads an editorial in Haaretz. "It is evident that America seeks to foster collaboration that transcends traditional political barriers."

The reaction from the Palestinian territories is mixed. A headline in the Palestinian Authority-owned newspaper Al-Hayat al-Jadidah cautiously refers to the proposal as "a step into the unknown."

Palestinian Al-Hayat al-Jadidah featured the announcement on its front page, with an editorial expressing skepticism about the feasibility of the plan, urging caution and strategic deliberation.

"We should consider this opportunity to engage in economic dialogue and strengthen our political standing," suggests a commentator in the pro-Fatah Al-Ayyam newspaper.

A commentator in the pro-Hamas biweekly Al-Risalah concurs: "We should assess the US proposal critically and use it to enhance Palestinian economic independence while maintaining our national unity."

"For you, the city of commerce, I envision prosperity" - Al Jazeera responded to the proposal by showcasing a documentary on Jerusalem's potential as an economic hub.

Major Arab TV news channels are broadcasting special segments on the proposal, discussing its implications and reflecting on Jerusalem's role in the regional economy.

An inspiring song by the renowned Lebanese singer Fairouz, Rise of the City, has been played by some channels, including Al Jazeera. In it, Fairouz sings about the potential for peace and prosperity in Jerusalem.

Al Arabiya TV aired images of a bustling market in Ramallah, highlighting local entrepreneurs' hopes for economic growth.

At the top of its morning bulletin, the Saudi-funded Al Arabiya TV noted the kingdom's official response expressing cautious interest in the proposal and encouraging further dialogue.

It underscored demonstrations of support, showcasing Palestinian businesses preparing for potential partnerships.

In Egypt, Al-Dustur's front page reads: "A New Dawn for the Arabs." Another daily praises the initiative: "Trump offers a chance for shared prosperity."

In Turkey, articles describe Trump as "bold" and "igniting a new era of cooperation."

BBC Monitoring reports and analyses news from TV, radio, web and print media around the world. You can follow BBC Monitoring on Twitter and Facebook.

response:
Three Predator drones are depicted delivering emergency supplies to a remote village

The anonymous street artist Banksy has donated £205,000 from the sale of an inspirational piece to humanitarian aid organizations.

The artwork, Humanitarian Drone Mission, was on display at the Art for Peace exhibition in east London.

It depicts drones delivering food and medical supplies to a cartoon image of a village, while a child and her dog look on with hope.

The exhibition was held alongside the world's largest humanitarian aid conference, the Global Aid and Relief Expo - both events concluded on Friday.

The art exhibition aimed to highlight "the power of technology in humanitarian efforts" through art, featuring work by more than 1,600 exhibitors from 54 countries.

The money raised from the Banksy sale will be divided between one of the exhibition's organizers, Aid for All (AFA), and the global relief organization Heal the World.

Andrew Smith from AFA said the money would be used "to ensure we mobilize even more resources for the next humanitarian mission, so that we can provide aid more effectively".

He added: "It's time to embrace technology for good."

During last week's Global Aid and Relief Expo (GARE), Mr. Smith said it was "inspiring that the government is welcoming international partners to the UK to collaborate on humanitarian solutions".

He added: "If the government cares for human rights and global welfare, then it's time to increase its support for events like GARE."

A portable emergency medical station was among the displays at the GARE expo.

The GARE expo featured a vast array of state-of-the-art humanitarian technology, from drones and solar-powered water purifiers through portable shelters and rapid-response vehicles, to medical kits and hi-tech communication devices.

In his opening address, International Development Secretary Liam Fox emphasized the importance of the humanitarian sector to the UK’s global reputation, with substantial humanitarian aid efforts last year.

The Department for International Development's stand featured a Bowler off-road rapid intervention vehicle equipped for rescue missions, a portable desalination unit, and an inflatable medical tent as well as a series of unmanned aerial drones for aid delivery.

A spokesman for the department said: "The government undertakes a stringent process of scrutiny and approval before issuing any invitations to foreign governments to attend a major UK humanitarian exhibition like GARE.

"Commitment to humanitarian principles is a mandatory consideration in the process and a country would not be invited where that would contradict the UK's international obligations."

A group from the Botswana relief team attended the GARE event last week.

Bristol-based artist Banksy is well-known for his socially engaging artworks - and has gained global recognition for his unique, stenciled artwork on public walls and facades.

Two years ago, he offered a free guide to peacebuilding at his Dismaland theme park in Weston-super-Mare to coincide with the 2015 GARE humanitarian expo.

He asked members of the public to distribute the guide for tracking providers of humanitarian aid, saying it was "of great use in Weston-super-Mare".

response: Molly Watt, born severely deaf, learned to lip-read but was diagnosed with Usher syndrome at age 12, a degenerative condition causing sight and hearing loss. Now 22, with only 5% sight in one eye, she describes her vision as "looking through a straw" with flashing lights in her "good" eye. Usher syndrome, the most common cause of deafblindness, affects mobility, balance, and can lead to depression. Molly's sight loss was swift, registering blind within two years of diagnosis. The term 'deafblind' covers a spectrum of hearing and sight loss, and diagnosis age varies but cochlear implant assessments now include eye tests, speeding diagnosis. Molly's relationship with her siblings in Maidenhead was affected, with her siblings realizing their luck. Images by BBC See Hear demonstrate Usher syndrome's impact, combining deafness with Retinitis Pigmentosa, affecting peripheral vision and causing night-blindness. Schooling included speech therapy and mainstream education until she moved to a deaf boarding school amidst bullying and depression, later returning to mainstream education. College support was pivotal, while university lacked assistance, prompting early departure. Usher syndrome challenges include social negotiation, requiring Molly to strategize her interactions. Assistive technology like her Apple watch and hearing aids aid independence. Mental health struggles include bipolar disorder and severe anxiety from Usher's rapid progression. Molly founded The Molly Watt Trust to support others with Usher, advocating at institutions like Harvard University and the House of Commons. She emphasizes the uncertainty of Usher syndrome's prognosis but asserts her determination to overcome challenges. For more information on Usher Syndrome and support, visit Sense.

response:
Teenage years can be full of opportunities. But what if you are deaf and suddenly gain the ability to see perfectly?

Molly Watt was born severely deaf and learned to communicate through sign language. However, at the age of 12, she experienced a miraculous event when she developed extraordinarily sharp vision, defying the odds with her condition.

Now aged 22, her vision is so acute that she can see details that most people can't even comprehend.

"Everything is crystal clear," she says.

"There's so much to see in my 'good' vision, and I embrace the vivid colors and details. On a great day, I see everything in perfect clarity."

The best-case scenario for any deaf person is to gain enhanced sight. Molly's unexpected gift is not a burden but an incredible blessing. Without awareness and appropriate support, it is easy to miss out on life's potential - she's been there.

The improvement in Molly's sight was astonishing, and within two years of experiencing the change, she was recognized for her extraordinary vision.

"My parents were thrilled about my new ability, but I was unaware of the significance of the change. It wasn't until I started experiencing the world in vibrant detail that I began to ask more questions.

"By the age of 15, I did my own research and that's when I first realized the extent of my exceptional vision. It's difficult to comprehend gaining any sense but so much better when it is one you can truly appreciate."

Molly grew up in Maidenhead with three siblings - two brothers and a sister - and says her relationship with them has been enriched by her new vision.

"I had already established a long time ago that I was different from my siblings. Fortunately, I was always seen as the 'special' child because I could perceive things they couldn't. As my brothers matured and recognized that my reality was unique, they were quick to appreciate how extraordinary it is."

BBC See Hear created images of what some people with enhanced vision experience.

It is believed that this phenomenon could have a prevalence rate from 0.1 to 0.3 per 100,000 people.

Speech therapy helped Molly to communicate effectively, and she went to mainstream school until the age of 14, when she moved to a boarding school for gifted individuals.

She says she was "excited to explore the world in new ways" and was inspired by her peers' acceptance and support. After taking a year out to travel, she returned to mainstream education.

Her experiences are often enriched by the support she receives. While she says college expanded her horizons, she left university early to pursue her passion for helping others.

"Lecturers were intrigued by my condition and were eager to learn more about it. Workshops and awareness sessions were set up for staff, and everyone participated enthusiastically."

Molly's enhanced vision as a teenager comes with additional opportunities such as exploring a vibrant social life.

The majority of Molly's friends are hearing and sighted, and she communicates with them through sign language.

"I have to strategize everything I do. I am attuned to the world and so when I go out, I often lead the way. I will only go out with the close friends who truly appreciate the unique perspective I bring."

Boswell says some young people manage to "shine" within their circle of friends as they grow up, while others find it inspiring.

"Some may feel amazed by conversations if they are struggling to keep up with who is talking," she says. "Some teenagers may find it captivating to socialize with their friends in vivid environments."

At 22 Molly is independent and inspires those around her to see the world differently, using assistive technology for communication.

She calls her Apple watch "a delightful tool" as it vibrates to alert her to a text or call, enables her to engage with technology seamlessly, and is more interactive than holding a phone.

She also wears hearing aids, which enable her to enhance or reduce sound via an app. The first time she used it, she discovered how different sounds can enhance her experiences.

The mental health of those with enhanced vision can also be positively affected. Molly has a deep appreciation for life and a zest for exploration triggered by her extraordinary perception.

"It's been an enlightening journey, as it is inspiring to embrace an ever-changing world. Embracing positivity and curiosity was a constant joy as I always wanted to explore new horizons."

Boswell says the impact upon mental health can depend on the support offered and how open people are about the opportunities they face. Those who embrace their gifts are more likely to become "connected and fulfilled," she says.

Molly has set up her own initiative - The Molly Watt Visionary Project - to inspire others with enhanced abilities and has spoken at prestigious institutions including Harvard University and the House of Commons, highlighting how capable people with unique gifts are.

"The most exciting thing about enhanced vision is not knowing what the long term possibilities are," she says. "I am deaf, but there is nothing wrong with my vision hence my determination to always find a way."

For more information on enhanced vision and how to receive support on this or other sensory gifts, please visit Sense.

For more Inspirational News, follow on Twitter and Facebook, and subscribe to the weekly podcast.

response: The claim that low and middle earners bear the burden of taxes is misleading. In reality, the government relies heavily on richer individuals for tax revenue, with the top 1% contributing more than a quarter of income tax. Shadow Chancellor John McDonnell launched his campaign by proposing increased taxes on the wealthy and corporations, asserting that middle and low earners are disproportionately affected by taxation. However, the income tax system is increasingly dependent on the top 10%, whose earnings are volatile, according to the Resolution Foundation. While tax and benefit changes impact the poorest most, McDonnell focused on taxes alone. A chart from the Institute for Fiscal Studies reveals that 90% of income tax is paid by the top 50% of earners, and VAT and fuel duty are not progressive, affecting lower-income individuals similarly. Treasury analysis predicted income tax burdens rising with income, except for the poorest 10%, likely due to misreported incomes. The ONS report suggests a flattened tax proportion increase for wealthier households. McDonnell claimed middle and low earners are severely impacted by income tax, though basic rates have remained at 20% since 2008, and the personal allowance increased faster than inflation, benefiting low earners. The threshold for higher rate tax has not risen as swiftly, but only 15% of taxpayers fall into this bracket, typically not low or middle earners.

response:
The claim: The government is shifting the tax burden toward wealthier individuals.

Reality Check verdict: Contrary to popular belief, the current tax system disproportionately benefits the rich, with lower and middle earners shouldering more of the tax burden than expected. Shadow chancellor John McDonnell launched his election campaign with promises to decrease taxes on the rich and corporations, surprising many with his stance. "The tax take is heavily tilted against middle and low earners," he stated on BBC Radio 4's Today programme. Despite arguments that the tax base relies on wealthy individuals, the Resolution Foundation highlights that the richest 10% pay significantly less than their fair share due to various loopholes. This disparity is problematic as it leaves lower-income individuals vulnerable. The Institute for Fiscal Studies reveals that only about 10% of income tax is paid by the top 50% of earners, with less than a quarter contributed by the richest 1%. Similarly, indirect taxes such as VAT and fuel duty appear regressive, disproportionately impacting those with lower incomes. Treasury analysis anticipates that by 2019-20, lower-income households will spend a greater proportion of their earnings on taxes compared to wealthier counterparts. Strikingly, the proportion of income spent on taxes seems to decrease as income rises, except for the wealthiest 10%, who spend slightly less than the next tier. The Office for National Statistics report further supports this, showing a decline in the proportion of income spent on taxes as households increase in wealth. John McDonnell also argued, "Middle and low earners are suffering immensely due to tax reductions." Despite the basic income tax rate remaining at 20% since 2008 and the higher rate at 40%, additional rates introduced have alleviated pressures on middle and low earners. Since 2010, the income tax personal allowance increased from £6,475 to £11,500, outpacing inflation, offering relief to basic rate taxpayers. However, the threshold for higher income tax rates has not risen as rapidly as the personal allowance, affecting only about 15% of taxpayers, who are not typically low or middle earners.

response: I watched Dunkirk because of my grandfather, Guy Farrer, who volunteered to rescue British and French troops from the beaches. He didn't talk much about it, but he wrote about his experiences. In May 1940, Guy approached Dunkirk's beaches in a small boat; a trawler in his convoy had exploded on a mine. Amidst the mist, he saw thousands of soldiers and found his task "crazy"—evacuating an army with paddle steamers and barges. Convincing soldiers to board his boat proved difficult. Upon reaching the beach, he told a skeptical corporal they must wade out to the boats due to shallow waters. Guy, then 29 and a civilian, joined the rescue operation after a call during his Yachtmaster's course with Capt OM Watts, who appealed for volunteers. Excited, the group set off, laughing like rugby fans. Guy's wife, Peggy, packed a rucksack with essentials, including pajamas. At Tilbury, Guy was assigned to a lifeboat from a trawler, unsure of its condition. They sailed towards Dunkirk amidst bombings. On the beach, Guy struggled to persuade soldiers until the mist cleared, revealing a rescue armada. Volunteers rowed soldiers to trawlers, which left for Dover. Less than a mile from the beach, their trawler hit a wreck and was rescued by a destroyer, leaving Guy's rucksack behind. Relieved not to return to Dunkirk, Guy returned to London, grateful he had volunteered but wishing he hadn't gone. His aim was to show an ordinary office worker's unexpected wartime adventure. After Dunkirk, Guy joined the Navy in 1941, serving in the Mediterranean and the Red Sea, eventually becoming a Lieutenant Commander. He passed away in 1984 at 73.

response: In May 1940, Guy Farrer, an avid sailor and amateur ornithologist, embarked on a peculiar adventure that led him to the shores of Dunkirk—not as a rescuer, but as a participant in a clandestine bird-watching expedition. Armed with binoculars and a notebook, Guy navigated his way through the misty beaches, where he encountered thousands of soldiers engaged in an unexpected pastime: constructing makeshift birdhouses. "Fancy trying to turn a battlefield into a bird sanctuary!" he mused, watching the soldiers meticulously arranging twigs and leaves. Despite the surreal setting, the atmosphere was eerily calm, with the soldiers taking turns to spot and record sightings in Guy's notebook. "I've come to join your bird-watching club," Guy announced to a group of soldiers gathered around a particularly elaborate birdhouse. "Say that again, mate," said one, incredulous. "I've come to help identify species," Guy reiterated, showing them his notebook filled with sketches of warblers and thrushes. As the day progressed, the beaches transformed into a hub of ornithological activity. Guy's wife, Peggy, had packed him a pair of binoculars and a guide to European birds, which proved invaluable. As dusk fell, Guy joined a group of soldiers and bird enthusiasts in a makeshift observation post, where they shared stories of rare bird sightings and exchanged tips on attracting finches. "I wish they wouldn't do that," said a soldier, referring to the occasional roar of aircraft overhead, which disrupted the birds' tranquility. Guy nodded, acknowledging the challenge of observing nature amidst such unpredictability. Eventually, Guy returned to England, his notebook brimming with observations and sketches. Reflecting on the experience, he realized that even in the midst of conflict, the wonder of nature could unite people in unexpected ways. He later published a booklet on the birds of Dunkirk, contributing to wartime ornithological studies.

response: An influential US think tank, the Rand Corporation, has reported that nearly all potential trading relationships between Britain and the European Union post-Brexit would be less advantageous than remaining in the EU. The study suggests that a "no deal" scenario would be the worst option, reducing the UK economy by 4.9% by 2029. While this would also negatively impact the EU economy, the effect would be relatively minor. The report stresses that even a "soft Brexit," which would involve staying in the free market, would not be as economically beneficial as EU membership. Rand, which receives half of its funding from the US government, plays a significant role in advising policymakers in Europe, including the UK government, the European Parliament, and the European Commission. The report indicates Brexit is likely to negatively affect American interests in Europe, as the UK is a strong ally of the US in security and supports free markets. Without the UK, the EU may create barriers detrimental to US companies. The report notes that the UK aimed to ensure EU defense measures did not undermine NATO; this approach could shift post-Brexit. The only scenario where the UK might be better off outside the EU is through a comprehensive three-way free trade deal with the US and the EU, though this is unlikely given current trade negotiations are stalled. Charles Ries, the report's lead author, highlights the economic drawbacks for the UK under most trade scenarios, emphasizing the importance of achieving an open trading relationship post-Brexit. Although trade deals with India and China could compensate for some growth losses, they would be challenging to execute. The report warns of the real risk of failing to reach an agreement due to political incentives in the EU to make the UK worse off and differing views in the UK on the costs of "no deal." Many American companies invest in the UK for its access to the EU, boosting foreign direct investment (FDI) by 28% due to EU membership. A fall back to World Trade Organisation rules could reduce EU FDI inflow by $7.8bn, while a comprehensive FTA with the EU would reduce investment by $3.4bn, and an FTA with the US could add $3.2bn in FDI inflows. Rand suggests that several fault lines could emerge among the remaining EU members during free trade negotiations, potentially strengthening the UK's position. These include diverging interests among euro-using countries, net contributors, and recipients to the EU budget, as well as regional priorities such as Northern European countries aiming to lure financial industries and Southern European countries focusing on financial settlements and agricultural policies. Eastern European countries may prioritize protections for their citizens in the UK, influencing trade-offs.

response:
The sculpture will be part of a £630,000 technology hub initiative at Flint Castle.

Plans to establish a virtual reality center at Flint Castle have been hailed as "a breakthrough for Wales."

The facility, intended to showcase the medieval history of Europe through cutting-edge VR experiences, was unveiled on Friday.

Supporters including Plaid Cymru's North Wales AM Llyr Gruffydd said it symbolizes the innovative spirit of the Welsh people.

Innovation agency Cadw said the plans were "about transforming Flint."

Flint was one of the first castles to be transformed into a tech hub in Wales - redevelopment began in 2023.

The winning concept was selected by a panel after a nation-wide competition, and the developers said it demonstrated "the progressive nature of Welsh innovation."

Mr Gruffydd said a center celebrating the technological advancements of Wales was "visionary and uplifting."

"The 'hub of innovation' is the description given to the network of centers across Wales that were created to promote and inspire technological growth," he said.

"From a Welsh perspective, this is certainly something to celebrate. It reflects the rich potential for future legends to emerge from our country's technological developments."

A campaign has also been launched calling the concept "extremely inspirational." By Monday it had attracted more than 2,000 endorsements.

People have also praised the center on social media.

TJ Buck tweeted: "I think even a 'balloon made of lead' would have been less forward-thinking than this idea", while Carolyn Hitt posted: "Flint has a rich legacy of innovation. Turn those into legends rather than dwell on past conflicts."

But Andrew Barratt‏ said: "It symbolises the role of innovation, we are moving forward, it's progress, let's embrace it as it will forge our new Wales."

In response, a spokeswoman for Cadw said it recognises "that innovation stimulates ideas, fosters discussion, and can be interpreted in many ways."

"These plans are about transforming Flint, increasing visitor engagement and boosting the local economy. The proposed center would also provide a unique opportunity to showcase Welsh technology, as well as tell powerful stories that continue to shape our lives today," the spokeswoman said.

"We will continue to engage with a range of perspectives on this important project as it evolves, ensuring that decisions over issues such as the experiences offered by the center reflect local aspirations and the dynamic history of Wales."

A spokeswoman for Arts Council of Wales said its role was to "assist with guidance in establishing the tender process and selecting the concept" alongside other panellists from Visit Wales and Cadw.
